head_text.subj: EXT. LANCASTER COUNTY, PA. COUNTRYSIDE DAY

text: The faces of several young children are presented in CLOS as they walk TOWARD US across a ploughed field. On the SO TRACK, the haunting SOUNDS OF A GREGORIAN FUNERAL CHANT. CAMERA PANS UP to the faces of older brothers and sisters then to parents and grandparents. These are not familiar  faces, but faces from another age, strong and open. All a dressed in the distinctive clothing of the Amish.
Through the last traces of early morning mist another gro of black-clad figures make their way down a lane.

An Amish buggy, black and highwheeled, stark against the  landscape, appears, a spirited chestnut in the traces. Framed in the glass window of the narrow buggy is the ste figure of an Amish man in black topcoat and flatbrimmed h his bonneted wife in muted colors, the face of a boy, att like his father, peering out. The horse's breath smokes on the frosty air, the buggy CR on its springs, and there's the rhythmic CLIP-CLOP OF HOO on the pavement.
Two Amish buggies reach a crossroads, join a procession o three others. They disappear as the lane wends through a  leafless thicket of hickory.
A BIG SHOT... now the procession numbers almost a dozen  buggies... it is headed toward a distant farmhouse.
Where literally dozens of carriages are parked. The horse have been taken from the traces, removed to the shelter o the barn.
As the black clad mourners begin to move into the house ( and children presumably first).
The coffin has the upper half open. We see that the corps has been dressed in white linen, a piece of white linen  partially covering the bearded face.

Partitions have been removed, making the central rooms of the farmhouse a spacious hall. The place is packed, a hun fifty or more Amish, all sitting in absolute silence on r of wooden benches. A wooden coffin rests on a bench in th f.g., and near it the close relatives of the deceased occ a special Place.

A young woman of perhaps twenty-seven. Her face is pale a drawn. In happier circumstances, although there haven't been too many of late in Rachel's life, we would see a robust, sen woman of full figure, spirit and intelligence. Eight-year-old SAMUEL LAPP flits next to his mother; he w appear stunned, possibly not entirely comprehending event And the patriarch, ELI LAPP; his stubborn, weathered  yet not unkind  features grief-stricken.
Their faces...
As it begins to CHIME nine a.m.
As he removes his hat. As one, the men in the congregatio remove their hats also. Then the preacher begins to speak in a formal German dial SUBTITLES OVER.
...a brother has been called home.  God has spoken through the death of  our neighbor, Jacob Lapp...
Where Rachel, Samuel and Eli are SITTING - SOUNDS of emot and grief not quite suppressed are heard throughout as:

...husband of Rachel, father to  Samuel, son of Eli. (and) His chair is empty, his bed is empty,  his voice will be heard no more. He  was needed in our presence, but God  needs such men, too. That one should  be taken so suddenly. Treat sorrow.  Still, we would not wish him back.  Rather we should prepare ourselves  to follow him.
TIGHTENING to the Lapps, and...

The mourners have gathered about the grave, standing in  silence as four pallbearers are lowering the coffin into pit. The many buggies are aligned in the b.g. As the pallbearers begin to shovel soil and gravel into t grave, the Preacher begins to read a hymn in German... a  slow atonal litany which seems to hang forever on the fro air.
TIGHTENING to her as the hymn continues...

Where the Amish have gathered for the traditional post  funeral, midday meals. Long tables are laden with customary Amishfare... crocks soup, hams, fowl, fried boiled eggs and pickled beets,  preserves and an infinite variety of pies and pastries.
Where she sits among women, accepting their condolences.

A brawny-armed, ruggedly-handsome, raffish looking Amishm There is something atypical about his face a slightly sar set of mouth, a bold eye, a prominent set of jaw. Not exa what old Jacob Ammann had in mind, maybe, but a well set- man nonetheless, and at ease among men. He's among a grou of men including old STOLTZFUS, the local healer, FISHER, BIEILER and Bieiler's stout young son, Tom.
Lapp was a good farmer. None better.
But not the man to buy a horse for  you. (and) Hochstetler, wasn't it your father  sold him that horse with a ruptured  testicle?
(grins) Told him it was a bee sting made him  limp that way.
(amused) That horse had one good ball. That's  all it takes.
The others chuckle. But Hochstetler's attention is still Rachel.

As Hochstetler looms on the horizon, plants himself like tree in front of her. At ease as he was with the men, he's a bit awkward at thi All the women, very much aware of Hochstetler's availabil tune in as Rachel looks up.
I was sorry to hear about Jacob. Let  us hope he walks close with God.
I'm sure he does, Daniel.

It is some time after the funeral and the Lapp family is  hard at work breaking ground for the spring ploughing. Th death of Jacob has increased the work load on all three   Samuel maneuvers a four-mule team while Rachel and old El work nearby, further breaking up the earth. Rachel looks from the back-breaking labor as several figures approach it's Daniel Hochstetler and two of his brothers. Without word they fall in beside Eli and Rachel and take up vario tasks associated with the work in hand. Daniel works close beside Rachel.

head_text.subj: EXT. COUNTRY ROADS, LANCASTER COUNTY DAY

text: A few BRIEF SHOTS of a lone buggy containing the Lapp fam take us from the 18th century into the 20th century the  reassuring RATTLE OF THE CARRIAGE WHEELS on quiet backroa to the ROAR OF TRAFFIC as the buggy waits patiently for a chance to cross a busy interstate highway.
A huge tractor trailer rig hovers over the frail buggy as trots down the interstate. The camera cranes up to reveal procession of vehicles behind the truck for a chance to  overtake it.
Daniel Hochstetler moves through the crowd on the plat-fo Rachel turns surprised, as he approaches, a faint color c to her cheek.
Daniel?
I... I was at the feed store. And I  saw your horse, so...
There is an embarrassment between them broken by the arri of the train.
You will come back soon?
Samuel can barely contain his excitement as he drags at h mother's hand.
Quickly, Mother Quickly!
Rachel embraces Eli.
You be careful out among them English.
She turns to Hochstetler.
I need time, Daniel.
Daniel Hochstetler leaps into the driving seat of his ope wagon and with a flick of the reins and a whoop sets his  horse off at a fast trot.
The ENGINE gives a WARNING BLAST before creeping slowly  forward.
As Samuel spots something out of the window that causes h to light up.
Look, Mama...!
A road runs parallel to the train track, and Hochstetler his wagon urges his horse almost to the gallop as he atte to keep pace with the train.
As Rachel smiles.
I see, darling.
And Samuel cranes to look back, waving, for as long as he can.
The train moves across a broad panorama of fields, dotted with dolls'-house-sized farms and the tiny figures of Ami farmers working their horse-drawn equipment.

As the train continues its eastward journey... Samuel sta raptly out of the window at the changing patterns of the  countryside. He points in wonder at a brightly colored ho air balloon as it drifts slowly over timbered hills... he looks unsure as the pattern of field and wood gives way t suburbs, bustling shopping centers, restaurants, car lots and fast food outlets.
As the train travels past dilapidated row houses, streets choked with cars and the gutters with filth.
Now Samuel is staring out the window with some confusion, almost apprehension:
Is this where we're going?
Of course not. We're going to  Baltimore. It's much nicer in  Baltimore.
And Rachel draws her son closer, turning her back on the  window.
Rachel is in a line at one of the counters. The plain dre of the two Amish  particularly Samuel's black coat and ha are drawing curious stares.
He's uncomfortably aware of the shy looks and giggles of little girl about his own age, standing in line with her  parents at the next counter. He edges away from his mothe

As Samuel comes upon a figure garbed in a long black froc coat and flat-brimmed hat... the man's back is turned, co from appearances, be an Amishman. Samuel stares... A beat, the man turns to face Samuel and discover that he is a Hasidic Jew.
As he reacts.
As Rachel's turn arrives. The TICKET SELLER glances up an she shows him her ticket.
We have a ticket to Baltimore. Where  is that train, please?
Delayed three hours. You'll hear an  announcement when it's time to board.
He starts to go without his hat, but Rachel collars him a puts it on his head.

As Samuel enters. It's a long row of sinks, urinals, and stalls... Samuel s before one of the urinals  a long, trough-like affair wit water drizzling down the rear porcelain panel. It's set a little high for Samuel, and it is making GLUGG FLUSHING NOISES that are, at least, intimidating. Samuel  stares for a moment, then turns, looks toward the stalls, stoops to see which are empty.
Beneath the row of doors we can see no feet visible. Samu is alone in the restroom.

As Samuel proceeds along the row of door, finally selects stall near the end. He enters. As he does so, a heavily  bearded youth in a dirty sweatshirt enters. With some urg he removes small notebook from his pocket and places it b a paper towel dispenser. Suddenly he glances up. Two other men have entered the men's room; one is a large BLACK MAN in a three-piece suit under an expensive, overc His PARTNER is a Caucasian in designer jeans, half boots a short leather jacket. They advance on the young man with unmistakable menace. The young man whirls in terror; his two assailants lunge him... a savage, wordless struggle ensues in the close  confines of the lavatory.
As the struggling men bounce off the door of his stall... can see their feet under the edge of the door.

As the struggle builds to a climax... ends with the young man stiffening with a grunt, his face draining of color. The two attackers step away, the blade in the black man's hand bloodstained. His partner stares at what they've  accomplished with a stunned expression:
Jesus...

The young man's hand comes away from his belly covered wi blood. He stares at it, staggers toward the sinks. Finally his  bloodied hand reaches to smear at his face in the mirror. Then he collapses to the floor. The black man motions for his partner to watch the door,  then quickly reaches up and removes the notebook from beh the dispenser.

As he edges open the stall door a crack. Over his shoulde we can see the black man, his BACK TO US, rifling the  backpack. But beyond him, in the mirror on the far wall, catch sight of the black man's face.
As he stares out the narrow crack. A beat, then he closes the stall door.
Samuel tries to make the latch work, but it's warped and  won't fall closed.

As he checks the notebook before placing it in his pocket His partner is covering the door, an automatic in his han The black man makes for the exit, then on second thought, glances at the row of stalls.
All quiet, but...
The black man whips out a .38 caliber revolver, and, star at the near end, starts pushing open the stall doors.
As the black man approaches, Samuel working desperately o the latch. At the last minute he finally wedges it in.
He elbows Samuel's stall... the door won't open.
Fighting back panic, Samuel has retreated as far as he ca
As he gives the door a kick. It holds. He swears under hi breath.

In desperation, Samuel does the only thing he can think o he slips under the partition into the neighboring stall t black man just checked out. But he loses his hat in the  process. His hand snakes back INTO FRAME to snatch it jus as the black man gives the door a ferocious kick that  splinters the lock and nearly takes it off its hinges. He framed there, the big muzzle of the .38 revolver looking  down our throats.
As his partner snaps from the doorway:
Will you come on, for Christ's sakes!
A beat, then the black man holsters his weapon, turns to  follow the partner out.
As we hear the SOUND OF THE TWO MEN EXITING the lavatory. long beat, then Samuel opens the stall door a crack.
Samuel's own face reflected in the blood-smeared mirror.. then PANNING DOWN to the still figure of the young man ly in the crimson pool of his own blood on the floor.

Samuel sits close to his mother, his face pale, his eyes  staring. Rachel holds his hand tightly in hers as the torsos of va police and officials pass through foreground, occasionall obscuring the lonely couple. There is considerable ECHOIN NOISE as commands and requests mingle with the CRACKLE OF TWO-WAY RADIOS.

The diffused shape of faces behind the frosted glass of t Men's room door, which is pushed open to reveal, JOHN BOO who comes striding through to be momentarily lost in the  crowd of police, reporters and others. He is about 40, wi a rangy, athletic body. Behind him comes CARTER, Book's b partner  about five years younger than Book. Book is wear a suit, Carter is much more casually  almost disreputably dressed.
Little Samuel watching Book, back to crowd of police, as  Book questions an old black CUSTODIAN.
You found the body?
Uh uh. Not me, daddy, I just reported  it. It was the kid.
What kid?
How'n hell do I know what kid? The  kid in the funny black threads.
Worry-eyed, still staring straight ahead. Then his eyes m suddenly to his left.
Coming in at full stride, then stopping.

He doesn't raise his eyes... just looks at the legs. And, slowly, the legs begin to bend at the knees. We see Book' belt buckle, then his big pistol in its holster, then his face. He stares at Samuel for a moment, then...
As his face breaks into a big grin, and...
Hi, kid.
Immediately alarmed, intervening.
What do you want of my son?
As Book takes out his wallet, displays his shield.
I'm a police officer. I'm going to  have to talk to the boy. What's his  name?
Samuel. Samuel Lapp. (then, quickly) But what happened here is none of  his affair. My sister is expecting  me... our train is leaving soon.

There'll be another train. (turns to Samuel) The man who was killed tonight was a  policeman, Sam. It's my job to find  out who did it. I want you to tell  me everything you saw when you went  in there.
(stammers) I saw him.
Who'd you see?
Sam looks at his mother.
Who'd you see, Sam? The man on the  floor?
No... I saw the man who killed him.
Book stares at him in surprise, speaks over his shoulder Carter.
Anybody know about this?
I didn't even know about it.
(back to Sam) Okay, Sam. Can you tell me what he  looked like?
(groping, touching  his clothes and  pointing at Carter) He was... like him.
(nods) Black... I understand. What else,Sam?
A beat, then Sam crosses quickly to Carter, Book's rather slightly built partner:
Not Zwartich, like him
Book frowns, puzzled:
Try that one again, Sam
Samuel gives his mother a helpless look; exasperated, Rac intervenes with Book. She glances at Carter:
May I talk to you?
As Rachel takes Book aside, and in a low voice:
Zwartich. It's the way we say...  dwarf. (glances at Carter) Not like him... very big.
Book nods, starts to turn back to Sam. Just then a commot off screen catches his attention.
It's Capt. TERRY DONAHUE, Chief of Homicide, striding pas the crowd of journalists and TV crews... brushing off  reporters' questions and snapping orders to the aides he' got in tow:
(to aides) Close it all down... I want a man on  every exit... I want the lab in here  now! (to Book) And I want to talk to you, Captain.
As Book steps aside with Donahue... In the b.g. Rachel mo protectively to Samuel's side.
All right, talk.
This is homicide  not Internal  Affairs! So why are you behaving  like you own this case?
We were running Zenovitch... That's  all I can tell you. But I want it,  Terry. (then) I've got a call into Schaeffer.
They can't help but watch the confrontation between Donah and Book... although they're keeping the volume down, it' obviously intense and angry:
(alarmed) Momma... are they angry with us.
(reassuring, but hardly  in her own mind) No... No. It is just the English  way.
Donahue has lost the confrontation; he gives Book a smile
You ought to think about coming back  to Homicide, Johnny... Stick with  Internal Affairs and you're not gonna  have any friends left.
(smiles right back) I'll buy a dog.
Book emerges from the terminal, looks about him, then cro to a big Mercury Sedan which is parked nearby. Two men si in the front seat. Book crosses to the driver's side and  opens the door.
Go get a cup of coffee, Stan.
The driver, a uniformed policeman, glances at the man bes him who nods in agreement. He gets out and Book gets in b the wheel.
Book sits next to SCHAEFFER, a surprisingly kindly lookin man of about fifty. Schaeffer is a Deputy Chief.
How reliable is this kid?
Oh, he's good.
Amish.
Yeah.
What have you got?
Zenovitch was about to deliver a  list of names tonight  street  chemists... the guys processing this  P2P into speed.
So one of them got to him.
Maybe.
You know who?
Maybe.
You're still convinced there's a  link to the department?
If there isn't I've just wasted the  last six months.

That's the problem. We need results.  The press is driving us crazy over  this P2P thing. Calling us the 'speed  capitol of the country'. You know  the sort of thing. It's getting  political. The Commissioner's getting  very uneasy.
The Amish boy saw him, Paul. I'll  make it, but Set Donahue and the  Homicide Department off my back or  they'll blow the whole thing.

When word gets out that Zenovitch  was a cop, all hell will break lose.  You've got 24 hours. That's all I  can give you. 24 hours on your own.  After that the case and the witness  go back to the Homicide Department.
(shakes his head) Tell you what... why don't you and  that blonde  what's-her-name  come  over for dinner Sunday. How 'bout  that.
What's-her-name moved to Buffalo.
(sighs) Well, anyway, don't get crazy. (dismisses him) I'll do something for Zenovich's  wife.

Book drives around 13th Street, a ravaged corridor betwee neon lit restaurants, bars, porno shops and darkened  storefronts. Carter sits beside him, Rachel and her son in the back se looking out at the assorted array of desperate characters huddled in doorways or wandering aimlessly about. On the  POLICE RADIO a description of the cop killing is BROADCAS EVERY FEW MINUTES.
I got there late, John.
Let's just find Coalmine. (beat) Listen, Zenovich made a mistake. You  didn't let anybody down. It happens
(grimly) It won't happen again.
Where are you taking us?
We're looking for a suspect. We've  reason to believe he's still in the  area.
You have no right to keep us here.
Yes I do. Your son is a material  witness to a homicide.
You don't understand, we have nothing  to do with your laws!
Doesn't surprise me. I meet a lot of  people like that.
It's not a joke.
Book decides to try contrition:
You're right. It's not a joke. Listen,  I know a little about the Amish. I  know this has to be an ordeal for  you; and I'm really sorry you an  Samuel got involved.
Samuel shoots a look at Book then mutters something to hi mother in German. She responds in the same language. Book frowns.
What was that?
He wants to know who you are. Your  name. I told him we don't need to  know anything about you.
Book eyes Samuel:
Book. John Book
Book's car stops, and from out of the shadows darts a wiz little MAN. He looks about before crossing to the driver' side window.
Book lowers the window.
Sammy, where's Coalmine?
The little man stares at the weird-looking couple in the  back seat.
What you got there, the Salvation  Army?
Coalmine.
Try "Happy Valley".

head_text.subj: EXT. HAPPY VALLEY BAR, SOUTH STREET NIGHT

text: Book's car pulls up outside the bar and he and Carter get out, and move swiftly inside.

Sixty black faces stare as the police enter. A hush falls the group. Book and Carter spot their man at the bar and  move up either side of him. They've moved carefully to th point... no mistakes. From the back, the black man they'v approached certainly looks like he could be the man who d the killing of Zenovitch. And, as Book and Carter make th move...

As Book and Carter explode through the door of the bar,  violently propelling Coalmine along with them. Now we see Coalmine is not the killer. As Book and Carter escort Coalmine out of the bar a polic squad car pulls up, its headlights shining into Book's ca An alarmed Rachel holds Samuel close as Book forces Coalm face down next to the car window.
Put some light on him.
A cop pulls out a flashlight, begins to play the beam ove Coalmine's face.
(continuing; to Samuel) Look at him.

Crazy as Rasputin on speed and booze, Coalmine glares at  Samuel inside the car: Samuel, white-faced, finally shakes his head in the negat Coalmine tries to twist free of Book's grip. Book snaps, slams Coalmine's skull into the window edge, finally crus his face up against the front window. His face takes on a grotesque shape against the glass. Carter restrains his  partner and Book cools down. Coalmine is led stumbling aw by the uniformed police. This sudden show of violence has horrified and angered Rachel, and she glares at Book as h gets back in the car.
John Book, you listen to me! I will  have no further part in this, nor  will my son! As God stands between  us!
Book sighs, starts the engine and moves off.
Book pulls up outside a hotel entrance as a uniformed DOO moves to open the rear door.
Rachel and Sam recoil as the Doorman opens the door. He i puzzled by the sight of the reluctant guests.
Ma'am?
No! We do not stay in hotels.
Book and Carter exchange a glance.
An attractive woman in her early thirties in robe and sli stares in disbelief as Rachel and Sam file into the house This is ELAINE, Book's sister. She stops Book as he tries follow Rachel inside.
How could you do this to me tonight?  I told you I had company
Sorry. It's important.
As she glances in a doorway.
It's a shambles, with dirty supper dishes piled sink, the table littered with empty beer cans.
As she hustles Samuel along.
Book frowns:
Where's Timmy and Buck?
Upstairs, asleep. Where'd you think?
You've got a man here and the kids  are upstairs?
That's none of your goddamn business!  So keep your goddamn holier-than- thou mouth shut! (and) Anyway, they like Fred.
Oh sure, Fred.
Elaine looks like she's going to blow again, then decides it's pointless.
Who are these orphans, anyway?
They're Amish.

Samuel is asleep in one twin bed in a tiny, cluttered roo Rachel, in a plain nightgown, is preparing to climb into other one. Off screen we hear a DOOR CLOSE, presumably Book leaving. beat, then Elaine opens the door and looks in.
Everything okay?
Yes, thank you very much.
(a beat) John said you're Amish.
Yes.
(blankly) Oh.
She nods and goes. Rachel crosses to Samuel, sits on the bed. Samuel looks u at her bleakly.
I don't want to stay here.
They are English. They don't  understand.
I wish dawdie was with us.
(swallows) I know. Sleep now, Liebchen.
She puts her hand on his forehead, closes his eyes. she  frowns, and...

head_text.subj: EXT. DRIVE-IN FAST-FOOD JOINT PHILADELPHIA DAWN

text: Carter exits the cafe carrying burgers, donuts and a coup of beers. Book wakes from a brief nap as Carter gets into the car. Book chews into his burger while Carter takes a doughnut. Its clear they've worked through the night.
Elaine's house is situated on the corner of a row of terr which stretch into the distance on both sides of the stre
As Samuel comes out of the guest room in his night-shirt, turns up the hall and opens the door to the bathroom.
But it's not the bathroom; it's Elaine's bedroom. She and FRED are tangled in the sheets, furiously making love. El gasps, Fred manages to grunt.
Wrong door, kid.
As Samuel quickly shuts the door. A straight-faced beat;  then, barely suppressing a giggle, he hurries on...
As Rachel appears in the living room entry. Samuel is sit on the floor with two boys of about his own age, watching television. They're eating cold cereal out of a box.
Some artless Saturday morning cartoon.
As she frowns, watching her son and the other two staring hypnotically. And...
It's later in the morning now, as Elaine, a bit blearily, appears in the entryway, stares in groggy disbelief.
Her oldest boy and Samuel are busily washing the windows  while her youngest is pushing a carpet sweeper. The TV is off.
As she stares.
Rachel is standing in the middle of the now immaculate ki finishing a brisk mop of the floor. The coffee is perking Elaine appears.
(mutters) Jesus...
Rachel turns cheerily.
Good morning.
(helplessly) You didn't have to...
I wanted to. you were kind to take  us in last night. (and) Anyway, I needed something to do. I  was so angry with your brother. He's  so... agaanisish!
Aganishish? Yeah, that sounds like  John.
She takes a seat at the table, still shaking her head.
Just a minute. I'll pour you some  coffee.
You're not carrying a bullwhip...  how'd you manage to put my kids to  work?
(smiles) I made it a contest... the one who  does best gets his cereal back first. (and) Children like to help... they only  need to be kept after a little bit.
Rachel means no harm by this, but Elaine's eyes begin to  storm.
Oh, is that so? (and) No offense, lady, but I'm not so  sure I like the idea of your coming  in here and turning the place upside  down!
Rachel's smile fades at Elaine's trembling outburst:
Please, I didn't mean...
Abruptly Elaine rises and snatches the mop from Rachel's  hands. She mops furiously as she Continues:

I know exactly what you meant! Listen,  maybe I'm not a world-class housefrau,  but maybe I don't have time to polish  the goddamn china and keep after the  kids! (and) It's none of your business, but I  don't happen to have a man around  here full time. So I sell cosmetics  in a goddamn drugstore and sometimes  I can even pay the rent on time! So  maybe I'm not Mary Poppins, but maybe  I don't need to have it jammed down  my throat like this.
She finishes the floor, hurls the mop aside with a CLATTE
There is that clean enough for you?
Rachel is speechless, Elaine is on the point of bursting  into tears. At which point Fred appears at the entry in h undershirt, taking in the sparkling kitchen.
Jesus, Elaine... Somebody die and  leave you a broom?
Not a politic observation on Fred's part.
(blurts) Go to hell, Fred!
And, bursting into tears, she flees the kitchen. Fred sta after her.
What's bugging her?
Unperturbed, he crosses to the counter and the coffee pot letting his eyes take in Rachel's full figure.
As Rachel comes in with Elaine's coffee, closes the door  behind her. Elaine is lying across the bed, sobbing.
I brought your coffee.
She takes a seat next to the bed.
I'm sorry. I didn't mean it that  way.
After a moment, Elaine starts to pull herself together:
It's okay. (and) Look, I shouldn't have blown my top.  It's like... somehow... I've let  everything get away from me. And you  sort of made me face it.
She takes the cup, sips the coffee. Rachel smiles at a pr thought.
What's so funny?
Fred. The way he looked when you  screamed at him.
(disparing) God, Fred...
At home you'd never hear a woman  scream at a man that way.
No? Why not?
You just wouldn't. It's not the Amish  way. (then) But I think it would have done me  good if I could have screamed at  your brother last night.
Listen, I don't know what's going on  or how you got mixed up with him,  but don't you let that self-righteous  son of a bitch push you around, okay?
Rachel smiles.
Okay.
Book glances irritably at Rachel:
Now what's the problem?
The problem is I don't happen to  think my son should be spending all  his time with a man who carried a  gun under his coat and goes around  whacking people.
Book gives her a look:
Whacking?
(firmly) Yes. And I also want to leave this  city.
Believe me, I'm trying to get this  over with as fast as I can. But Samuel  will probably have to come back and  testify.
We do not go into your courts.
People who don't go into our courts  when they're told to sometimes go  directly into our jail.
Rachel glares at him and the ride continues on that chill note for a beat.
Look, I'm genuinely sorry...
(snaps) No you're not  (off his look) You're glad, because now you've got  a witness. (and) I heard the other police talking  last night. (and) They don't seem to like you very  much.
They kid a lot.
(glances at him) I would not be too sure.
Samuel has been glancing at Book; finally he says somethi to his mother in German. Book gives her an inquiring look
He says you look very tired. I thought  the same thing.
Book says nothing.
But not a good tired.
What's a 'good' tired. Tired is tired.
She doesn't bother to explain; Book settles even deeper i his funk as Samuel glares at him with hostility.

head_text.subj: INT. IDENTIFICATION ROOM POLICE H.Q. DAY

text: Samuel sits with Book at a desk, Rachel just behind. They are looking at a police line-up of known black drug-deale Samuel shakes his head  another negative. Book winks, slyly reaches into a pocket, produces a yello gumball. He surreptitiously shows it to Samuel, gives him inquiring look. It's a peace offering. Samuel grins, nods imperceptibly.
As Book rolls the gumball down the table to Samuel. But j as Samuel is about to cover it with his hand, Rachel reac over and plucks it off the table. She shakes her head at  Samuel.
(to Rachel) Just wanted to see if you were on  your toes.
Book, Sam and Rachel sit on a park bench eating a lunch o hot dogs heaped with kraut. Book watches with amusement as Samuel wolfs down his lunc Rachel eyes him a beat. then:
Your sister said you don't have a  family?
No.
She thinks you should get married  and have children of your own. Instead  of trying to be a father to hers.  Except she thinks you're afraid of  the responsibility.
Book gives her a look:
Oh? Anything else?

Oh yes. She thinks you like policing  because you think you're right about  everything. And you're the only one  who can do anything. And that when  you drink a lot of beer you say things  like none of the other police would  know a crook from a... um... bag of  elbows.
Book is staring at her. Rachel nods.
I think that's what she said.
Just then Samuel belches with huge satisfaction, drawing  looks from Book and a couple of passersby. Rachel smiles  proudly.
Good appetite.

head_text.subj: INT. OUTER OFFICE/WAITING ROOM, NARCOTICS DIVISION DAY

text: Rachel sits uneasily in the outer office, one or two poli clerks eyeing her curiously. A sign on the desk reads  "Narcotics Division." Rachel cranes forward trying to peer through a partially  open door.

location: DETECTIVES ROOM, NARCOTICS DIVISION, POLICE H.Q. DA

text: A group of Narcotics Detectives are interrupted in mid  conversation by the opening of the main office door. They stare in considerable surprise.
Standing in the doorway, holding little Samuel by the han
Afternoon, gentlemen. I'd like you  to meet Samuel Lapp. We'd like a  little help.

head_text.subj: INT. SMALL OFFICE, NARCOTICS DIVISION DAY

text: A Narcotics Detective enters the room laden with several  volumes of mug shots. He puts them on the desk beside a  similar book which Samuel is intently studying. Sam sits the chair cushions in a big swivel rocker. The Detective, SGT. KAMAN, eyes Book a little suspiciousl internal affairs officers are not greeted warmly by the  working policemen in any department.
There's a Sgt. Carter on the phone  for you.
Book gets up and moves to the door.
And, Captain, don't want to rush  you, but I'm gonna need these files  back in a half hour. We got a lot of  work to do round here.
The two men leave. Samuel looks about before hopping off perch and following the direction taken by Book.

head_text.subj: INT. DETECTIVES ROOM, NARCOTICS DIVISION DAY

text: Through glass partitions we can see Book on the telephone a cubicle of an office. Samuel has drifted out of the office and is idling amid t bustle of the squadroom. He crosses to a glass case which holds a collection of pl and framed newspaper accounts which denote instances of  outstanding duty and achievement.
As Samuel moves along, only half interested in what his e are taking in, not really old enough to comprehend anyway Until suddenly he freezes.

Enlarged, prominently displayed. The headline reads: "Div Chief McElroy Honored For Youth Project". Accompanying th item is a large sidebar mug-shot of McElroy  clearly the  black man who murdered the young cop in the train station men's room.

He stares, transfixed. A long beat, then Book, lowering himself to one knee next Samuel, ENTERS FRAME. He's watching Samuel, knowing from the boy's expression t they've found their man. Samuel slowly raises his hand to point at the photograph. Book gently takes the boy's smal hand in his, concealing the accusation from watchful eyes He smiles gently at the boy.
Rachel is curled tight in her corner of the front seat ho Samuel close. Book glances at her:
Why don't you arrest that man? Are  you protecting him because policeman?
(snaps) Listen, I'm the cop that polices the  police. I'm not in the business of  protecting crooked cops. (eases up) I'll make an arrest when I know  everybody involved.
Rachel shakes her head.
But why would they murder...

Because  somehow  they knew I was  getting close. (and) Look, it's narcotics... They make  dope out of chemicals... they sell  it on the street for millions of  dollars. They'll do anything. (and) And they can get away with it because  they're cops.
(beat, then) I'm afraid. I'm afraid for Samuel. I  want to go home.
You'll be safe. You don't have to  worry.
She says nothing. Another beat, then:
Look, they're thinking as long as  they keep the killer out of Samuel's  way, we can't make an I.D. There's  no way they can know Samuel saw that  photograph, so he's safe.
He glances at her, but she continues ahead.
I mean it. You will be safe.
Suddenly Rachel explodes:
Oh yes! Of Course. Why shouldn't we  feel safe in a city where the police  are so busy killing each other!

head_text.subj: EXT. / INT. SCHAEFFER HOME, PHILADELPHIA SUBURBS NIGHT

text: The front door of Schaeffer's upper-middle class home is  opened by his wife MARILYN. She knows Book and is surpris and delighted to see him. In the background daughter KATH is visible. Schaeffer himself appears and Book is welcome inside.
Schaeffer passes Book a drink. Book is excited, animated... the hunter, after a long cha closing on his quarry:
It was McElroy, Paul.
Schaeffer gives him a sharp look:
Last guy I would have figured. But  he's part of it.
I hope you don't have any doubts  about that.

If I did, I'd have kept my mouth  shut... (and) It fits, Paul... Fifty-five gallons  of P2P confiscated four years ago...  Guess who was in on the collar? Mac. (excited, explaining  the thing eagerly) He salts it away somewhere... he  knows the stuff is potent, but the  street chemists haven't figured out  how to process it. But they do now. (and) And now the stuff is worth five-grand  a pint and there are a lot of pints  in a fifty-five gallon drum.
(beat) Who else knows?
Just us.
(shakes his head) Okay, what are you going to need to  clean it up
More people... Gotta pick up where  Zenovich left off. People from outside  the department.
(nods) Maybe the Bureau. Or those bastards  at Treasury. I'll take care of it. (then) I hate this shit, Johnny. You cut  their balls off for me. I'm counting  on you.
Schaeffer pours himself another drink.
What's your first move?
(expels a breath) A hot shower... I haven't changed  clothes in two days.

Book slams the front door of his car, checks it for being locked, glances at a roiled newspaper in his hand (the sp section of the Inquirer), starts across the parking lot t his apartment, walking as he keeps glancing down at the s section. He comes to a sort of crosswalk, stops, reads, s to take a step... and looks up.
McElroy, smiling nicely, starting across toward him from other side of the parking lot crosswalk
Freezing, eyes widening. Utterly surprised and caught.

Still smiling, he brings up his right hand out of a shopp bag (which he appeared to be carrying)  letting the shopp bag fall away as he does so  revealing a five-inch barrel Smith and Wesson .357 blue finish revolver with a silence Without hesitating, coming right on, still smiling, he FI once.
Already starting to leap away to one side, he is hit, dri into a half-turn. He clutches at the wound, as:
Coming right on, FIRING again... the pistol's report a  WHOOSHING, like the opening of a bottle of cheap champagn And McElroy still smiling as:
Hit... a grazing near-miss this time, but enough to send  Book down hard and grasping.
Lowering the pistol alongside his leg, as two MEN, barely taking notice of anything, cross with their backs to Book toward McElroy. He smiles at them.
Down, muttering CURSES.
As McElroy walks past Book, drops the pistol to the pavem keeps on going... and is gone.
GROANING in pain, beginning to try to crawl crab-like. An we HEAR  from the agonized recesses of Book's Dream.
Who else knows?
Just us.

As the lights of an oncoming car  going very slowly, on i way to a parking space  sweep over him and we HEAR it com to a sudden, squealing stop. Book is already trying to ge to his feet... now succeeds, lurching into a swaying stan using an adjacent car for support. OFF SCREEN we HEAR a c door slam, and footsteps hurrying in our direction,  accompanied by excited voices. Book HEARS, turns to face oncomers,
A fat, middle-aged MAN has approached to within some feet Book, looks on edgily:
Hey, buddy, what's the score? Little  too much to drink?
Book stares at him, then looks down at his belly.
As Book removes his hand we can see one of the bullets st him low in the side, just below the ribcage... the other  just above it (but this one inflicting only minor damage)
As the man stares:
Goddamn, buddy. You better get to a  hospital! (and) Here; I'll give you a hand.
He starts to approach, but Book shoves him away.
No! No hospital!
By now the man's WIFE is hovering at a safe distance:
Let him alone, Henry! If he wants to  die in the street, that's his  business!
But the man is not content:
Shut up, Romona! Will ya look at  that blood?
Book has tried to lurch toward his car; the man tries to  intercept him:
Come on, buddy... you're gonna bleed  to death!
Book whirls on him, his service revolver in his hand poin squarely at the fat man's face:
Shit!
(quavering) I told you, Henry!
Book doesn't trust himself to speak, but the .38 is  sufficiently eloquent for the circumstances, He stares at the fat man another beat, then hesitates, turns, starts b toward his car.
As Book's car wheels somewhat erratically through traffic
Book has a gym bag open on the seat next to him, is stuff a tshirt under his belt to staunch the blood. And...
As he's awakened by the RINGING bedside telephone. He sna on a lamp... He's instantly awake, not unused to such rou in the wee hours. A woman sleeps beside him.
Yeah...
He's at an n.d. pay phone.
Listen carefully, I wrote the Amish  woman's name and address on my desk  calendar, I want you to lose it for  me, Now. Tonight.
What the hell are you talking about? What's happening.
Nothing. I'm not going to be around  for a while. I'll call you when I  can.
(alarmed) Johnny, what the fuck?
(hard) Listen to me  Schaeffer's part of  it. Maybe at the top of it.
There's a stunned silence at the other end.
Yeah... I can put it all together  when I get back, 'Til then, you know  nothing, understand? Business as  usual...
(beat) I hear you.
(nods) Good. Take care of that woman's name  for me. And watch your ass.

head_text.subj: INT. GUEST ROOM, ELAINE'S HOUSE NIGHT

text: As the door opens and Elaine switches on the light, rousi Rachel. Elaine looks haggard.
It's John. He says you have to leave  now. He says it's urgent.
She leaves the room as Rachel instantly awake, moves quic to rouse Samuel.
Elaine is outside the bathroom listening to instructions  from her brother. From inside we hear the SOUND OF RUNNIN WATER. Elaine is puzzled but also senses the urgency.
Put my car in the garage and close  the door.
John, I don't understand any of this.
(snaps) You don't know anything... borrowed  your car. Didn't say why. And you  never heard of that woman and her  boy.
John, why?...
(shouts) Just do it!

Book looks at himself in the mirror, his face is pale and drawn. He examines the wound, a cleanly drilled hole through his right side, just under the rib cage. The wound continues bleed as he binds a towel tightly about him, before putti his shirt back on. He then carefully wipes away any traces of blood on basin with tissues which he flushes down the toilet.
As he drives across town. Samuel is curled up asleep, his head on Rachel's lap.
Where are you taking us now?
Home.
You couldn't wait until morning?
Book gives her a look.
(insistent) What happened?
But Book, glancing in his rearview mirror, tenses.
In it we can see a police car coming on fast, with lights and SIREN.
Rachel eyes Book warily. A beat, then the police car WAILS past. Book expels a bre
You said we would be safe in  Philadelphia.
I was wrong.
Rachel looks away, speaks almost sarcastically, MUTTERING
Kinner un Narre... ["Kinner un Narre saage die Waahret"  "Children and fools say the truth"  Amish expressions]
ANGLE PAST Book's desk calendar. Carter enters in the b.g crosses quickly to the desk. He snaps on a light, thumbs page of the calendar. Frowns.
Rachel's name and address scribbled on a page of the cale
A couple of plainclothesmen have paused outside the door give him a look. Meets their eyes. They move on. Carter shakes it off, goes. And...
As light colors the eastern horizon, Book is crossing int Lancaster County. Book glances at Rachel; she's asleep. He coughs wrackingl hurting... cinches the belt of his overcoat even tighter. And...
Coming up the long drive.
As the car pulls up in the barnyard and Eli crosses to it Suddenly the car door flies open and Samuel jumps out, ra across the barnyard to hurl himself into the old man.
As Rachel steps out of the passenger's side, Book remains seated. He lets his eyes travel around the farm.
Stay for awhile. Rest. I'll make  coffee and breakfast.
I can't.
What about Samuel? Will you come  back to take him to trial?
Book starts the engine:
(grimly) There isn't going to be one.
Rachel stares at him, not sure what he means. Then backs  away, closing the door. Book begins to turn the car aroun in the barnyard.
As Eli crosses to Rachel, his arm around Samuel.
Who was that man?
His name is John Book.
Eli is about to inquire further when Samuel cries:
Momma  look.
They glance in the direction Samuel is looking.

The car has failed to take a bend in the road and is now  bouncing across an adjoining ploughed field. It's knocked over a tall birdhouse by the roadside. The car finally co to rest against a bank of earth.
She stares...
As Samuel races for all he's worth across the field,  negotiates the creek via a fallen log  Rachel, now, also  running toward the car.
Eli works fast harnessing his mules to an open wagon. He  hops up to the front seat and urges them to trot.
We see that Rachel has made Book as comfortable as possib in the front seat of the car and is packing the wound und his trenchcoat with material ripped from her apron.  Momentarily he comes awake:
But John... why didn't you go to a  hospital?
No, no doctor...
(bewildered) But why?
Gunshot... they'll file reports...  they'll find me.
But
Book reaches up to grip her arm fiercely:
And when they find me, they'll find  your boy!
He slips under again. Rachel stares at him, realizing the price he's paid in returning them to safety. She reaches out, touches him gently. But the moment is broken by...
As Eli reins up in the springwagon. He climbs down, cross to glance into the car.
Is the English dead?
No...
Looks dead...
And together they begin to lift Book from the car and pla him in the back of the springwagon. And...
Where Eli is looking out a window.
An Amish buggy coming up the drive, past Book' s car.
Where Book lies on a bed. Rachel is bathing his wound wit warm water from a pan. Eli appears in the doorway.
Stoltzfus is coming.
Rachel looks at him, nods. Eli frowns at Book's holstered pistol lying atop his neat folded clothes on a chair near the bed.
That has no place in this house.
I know.
She picks up the pile of clothes and the pistol and place them in a chest.
It will go when he goes.
As Samuel comes in with old Stoltzfus and Stoltzfus's tee son, LEVI.
Thank you for coming, Stoltzfus.
Stoltzfus's eyes have gone to the bed:
That's the English is it?
As Stoltzfus runs his fingers lightly over the vicinity o Book's wound:
I feel... burning.
As Stoltzfus, in his shirt sleeves and concentrating migh moistens his fingertips with saliva, continues the  examination. Finally he steps back.
This man should be treated in town. (indicates) The bullet entered there... and came  out there. But there is the danger  of infection, and he has lost a great  deal of blood.
Rachel looks at Stoltzfus, then turns away, torn by her  dilemma. Her eyes fall on Samuel. Gently she ushers him from the r
Go help Levi with the car, Samuel.
She closes the door after him, then turns to face Eli and Stoltzfus:
No, he must stay here.
Stoltzfus gives Eli a puzzled look. And:
Didn't you hear Stoltzfus? What if  he dies? Then the sheriff will come.  They'll say we broke their laws
We'll pray that he doesn't die! But  if he does, then we'll find a way so  no one knows!
Rachel, this is a man's life, we  hold it in our hands.
I know God help me, I know that,  Eli. (then) But I tell you that if he's found  here, the people who did this to him  will come for Samuel.
Rachel beseeches them helplessly:
What else can we do?
Levi has hitched Eli's mules to the rear of Book's car an is towing it up the drive toward the barn, with Samuel  catching a ride on the bumper.
Where she's waiting with the big barn doors thrown open. the mules tow the car in, she closes the doors.
As Stoltzfus and Levi are about to go: Stoltzfus turns to Rachel:
Make a poultice... three parts milk,  two parts linseed oil... for the  infection.
I'll send Mary by with some teas I will brew myself.
Thank you.
Stoltzfus turns to Eli:
Lapp, I'll have to speak with the  diener on this matter.
(nods) As you see fit, Stoltzfus.

As Rachel enters, turns up a kerosene lamp which is burni low at bedside. She's carrying the poultice Stoltzfus ord Book's brow is beaded with sweat. Rachel seats herself next to the bed, strips away the swe soaked sheet. Her eyes take in his bare torso, and we sho get the feeling that there's rather more male animal on  display here just now than she's quite comfortable with. She begins to apply the poultice.
As Book rouses to semi-consciousness, in his delirium he  recoils with alarm.
It's all right! You have got to lie  still.
Book stares up at her without recognition, but some of wh she says seems to penetrate. He quiets.
(soothingly) Yes, much better...

As Book lapses back into sleep. Rachel hasn't removed her hand from his chest. Abruptly she does so. She finds herself wondering about this man lying before h so suddenly a part of her life. She notices details; brui scars, the knuckles are hard, grazed, a tattoo on one  shoulder. While lost in this reverie, the delirious  Philadelphia policeman begins to mutter. Incoherently at  first, then the words take shape  swear words; curses; fu this and that; shit; etc. Rachel rises abruptly, her chee coloring, as the barrage of language pours from his mouth She beats a hasty retreat closing the door swiftly behind her.
He's on the phone:
Looks like we're going to need some  help from you folks down there.

head_text.subj: INT. LANCASTER COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE DAY

text: Where an UNDERSHERIFF is on the phone:
...want to help any way we can, Chief,  but you got to understand we've got  upwards of seven thousand Amish over  here.
And that's just Lancaster County.
Who is trying to control his impatience:
I've got the woman's name, Sheriff.  Lapp. Rachel Lapp. That should  simplify your work.
The Undersheriff frowns. He doesn't like being talked dow to.
How about an address?
Ah... no.
(frowns) Maybe a road or route number?
Sorry.
The Undersheriff is not impressed.

Problem is, Chief, 'bout every third  Amishman around here is named Lapp.  That or Yoder. Or Hochstetler. (and) Chief, if the Amish have taken your  man in, I wouldn't want to hang from  a rope until you find him.
Schaeffer is tight-lipped with contained fury:
Thank you, Sheriff. It's been an  education.
He hangs up. A beat; the man is a study in frustration. T he glances up.
Standing in his doorway are the two plainclothesmen who  spotted Carter in Book's office in the earlier scene. And
A bright, sunny afternoon.
Where he's leading a team of horses to the barn. In the b three buggies are parked in the barnyard, traces empty.  Visitors.
Where Book lies in the bed. His fever seems to have subsi He's coming awake, tries to focus on the room.

PANNING the four men in Amish black who are standing arou the bed looking down at Book, muttering among themselves German. These include TSCHANTZ, the district bishop, a hawk-nosed sterneyed old fellow; Stoltzfus, a deacon as well as a he and two preachers, ERB and HERSHBERGER. Eli stands somewh apart.
Another moment of silence, then Book opens his eyes. Tschantz rumbles in German. SUBTITLES OVER.
Well, Stoltzfus, another Lazarus to  your credit.
He was touched by God's hand.
Tschantz grunts, motions, for the other clergy aside with him. Rachel enters briskly with a steaming pot of tea and a cu smiles.
Hello.
Book stares at her, then at the old bearded gentlemen.
(closing his eyes) Who are they?

The leadership of our district...  the diener. Bishop Tschantz is the  one with no hair on top. They decided  to come and see you for themselves.  Except Stoltzfus, of course. He came  the first day. I think he saved your  life.
Can I have something to drink?
Rachel brings him tea.
Does anybody know I'm here?
Only the elders.
How long?
What?
How long have I been here?
Two days.
(a beat) Listen, thank you. Thanks for  everything. But I've got to go.
(frowns) But you can't.
He tries to rise, falls back faint. Rachel rearranges the sheet.
See. Anyway, you don't have any  clothes on. And besides that, Bishop  Tschantz wants to talk to you when  you feel better.
The elders appear to have concluded their conference, and are filing out. Stoltzfus pauses at bedside.
Rest, Mr. Book. That's the ticket.  And drink my of my tea.
He goes. Book is still fending off the dizziness. Rachel  puts the teacup to his lips.
Tell him his tea stinks.
(smiles) You tell him. When you're able.
He looks like he's about to drop off again. Rachel rises.
(from the door) We're all very happy that you're  going to live, John Book. We didn't  quite know what we were going to do  with you if you died.
That penetrates for a moment just before Book slips into  sleep again.
As the rather worrisome Hershberger frowns:
...but a gunshot wound. Very serious.
It is not the first time we have  done this. In the Englischer war of  the revolution, old Elmer Miller's  grandfather took in gunshot English  soldiers. (a tad of pride) Saved them, too.
They all nod. What Tschantz says is well known. Then:
Still, he should be among his own  people.
Rachel enters on this last.
He'll leave as soon as he is able.  He already wants to go.
Hershberger gives her a gloomy look, turns to Stoltzfus:
How long will that be, Stoltzfus?
(shrugs) A month. Maybe less. With God's  healing love.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOOK'S SISTER'S HOUSE PHILADELPHIA DAY

text: Schaeffer is knocking at the front doors. A beat, then El opens it cautiously, peers out.
(half fearfully) Did you find him?
Not yet.
Suddenly her eyes blaze, she starts to close the door:
Then go away, you bastard.
Schaeffer quickly  but gently  prevents her from shutting it.
Elaine, I've come to apologize for  Lt. McElroy. He overstated the  department's position.
(bitterly) He accused John of taking kickbacks.  And you know  anybody who knows  John  knows that's a goddamn lie!
(smoothly) Of course, Elaine. But as long as  there's any question, better Johnny  should come back and clear his name.
(cuts in) Better you should get off my front  porch before I get my mace!
Elaine, I don't want to have to take  you in for questioning. You've got  his car, you were the last to see  him
(clipped) I don't know where he is.
But... if you had to guess?
McElroy watching.
We see a final exchange between Elaine and Schaeffer. Ela forces the door shut. Schaeffer turns, walks slowly to hi car.
As Schaeffer opens the door, climbs in, sinks wearily int the seat, beside McElroy.
She say where he is?
I don't think she knows.
Schaeffer is staring grimly ahead.
What about Carter?
Tight. But I'm working on him.
Lean on him.

head_text.subj: EXT. LAPP FARM LANCASTER COUNTY NIGHT

text: REESTABLISHING, and TIGHTENING to the upstairs sickroom w where a lamp dimly burns.

As Samuel comes in with a fresh bedpan. Book is lying asl on the bed. Samuel puts the bedpan down, checks to make sure Book is  indeed asleep, then quietly crosses to the foot of the be and opens the clothes chest.

Book's big .38 revolver lies holstered atop his folded  clothes. Fascinated, Samuel picks it up, admiring the heavy burled pistol grips. Unable to resist, he starts to remove the w from the holster, then pauses to steal a look. OFF SCREEN
His eyes are open and watching Samuel icily, which gives boy something of a jolt.
Give me that.

Mutely, Samuel hands Book the pistol from arm's length. H looks on as Book takes the pistol out of the holster, sho the boy another look, then snaps open the cylinder and sh out the heavy, copper-jacketed bullets into his palm. He  snaps the cylinder closed again, then nods to Samuel.
Come here.
The boy edges closer.
You ever handle a pistol like this,  Samuel?
(swallows) No pistol. Ever.
Tell you what  I'm going to let you  handle this one. But only if you  promise not to say anything to your  momma. I've got a feeling she wouldn't  understand.
(grins) Okay, Mr. Book.
Book smiles. Then he gives the boy a playful, John Wayne- tough guy wink as he cocks and uncorks the pistol,  demonstrating the action. He finally hands it over to Samuel, butt first.
Call me John.

The boy tries to imitate Book's one-handed expertise, but his hands are too small. Book smiles. Samuel finally manages to get the thing cocked, using two hands, and Book reaches over to guide the muzzle away so  that it's not pointed at him.
You don't want to point that at people  you just started calling by their  first name.

Samuel levels the pistol at the door and, just as he snap the trigger, Rachel enters, pulls up short in some dismay find her son has a gun pointed at her. Samuel blanches an Book winces, knowing there's heavy weather ahead.
(snaps) Samuel!
Samuel quickly hands the pistol back to Book, who holster it:
Wait for me downstairs.
Samuel quickly exits, and Rachel angrily advances on Book
John Book, I would appreciate it if,  during the time you are with us, you  would have as little to do with Samuel  as possible.
Nobody meant any harm. The boy was  curious. I unloaded the gun -
It's not the gun. Don't you  understand... It's you. What you  stand for. (and) That is not for Samuel.
Book looks at her thoughtfully. Rachel softens a bit:
Please, it has nothing to do with  you personally.
He hands her the holstered gun and the loose bullets.
Put it up someplace Samuel can't get  it.
A beat, then Rachel, takes the pistol and starts to go. B stops her:
Friends?
Rachel glances back at him, smiles and nods. And...

Book's holstered gun and bullets at center table. Eli sit on one side, a chastened Samuel on the other. Rachel look on from the b.g. Eli knows that this is as important a dialogue as he will ever have with his grandson: at issue is one of the centr pillars of the Amish way.
The gun  that gun of the hand  is  for the taking of human life. Would  you kill another man? Eh?
Samuel stares at it, not meeting his grandfather's eyes. leans forward, extends his hands ceremonially.
What you take into your hands, you  take into your heart.
A beat, then Samuel musters some defiance.
I would only kill a bad man.
Only a bad man. I see. And you know  these bad men on sight? You are able  to look into their hearts and see  this badness?
I can see what they do.
Now he meets Eli's eyes:
I have seen it.
Eli expels a deep sigh; then:

And having seen, you would become  one of them? (intent... gesturing) Don't you see...? The hand leads the  arm leads the shoulder leads the  head... leads the heart. The one  goes into the other into the other  into the other... And you have  changed, and gone amongst them...
He breaks off, bows his head for a moment. Then he fixes boy with a stern eye and, driving he heel of his palm fir into the tabletop with enormous intensity:
"Wherefore come out from among them  and be ye separate, saith the Lord!"
(indicating pistol;  continuing from  Corinthians 6:17) "And touch not the unclean thing!"
His intensity tinged with righteous anger, he is hugely  impressive.
Book stands near the door to the kitchen, and has heard m or all of Eli's words. He turns, and painfully makes his into the washhouse, moving quietly, hoping no one will co out from the kitchen.
Samuel harnesses up the family mare, and backs her into t traces of the buggy.

Book stands at the window in a worn robe. Below, through window, we can see Samuel and Eli in the barnyard. A beat then Book crosses impatiently back to his bed, sits down, picks up a dog-earred copy of The American Dairyman. Ther a stack of well-thumbed farm magazines and copies of The  Budget (the Amish newspaper) on the bedside table. There's a knock. Rachel enters carrying a pile of clothin She smiles.
Enjoying your reading?
Very interesting. I'm learning a lot  about manure. (eyes the clothing) What's that?
Your shirt and jacket are still  stained with blood. I have them  soaking.You can wear these.
She passes the clothes to Book.
Your husband's?
Yes. It's good that someone can have  the use of them. Besides, in your  clothes you'd stand out to strangers.
She continues, cheerfully.
I should tell you these do not have  buttons. (shows him) See? Hooks and eyes.
Something wrong with buttons?
Buttons are Hochmut.
Hochmut?
Vain. Proud. Such a person is  Hochmutsnarr. He is not plain.
(nodding) Anything against zippers?
(almost blushing) You make fun of me. Like the tourists. Driving by all the time. Some even  come into the yard. Very rude. They  seem to think we are quaint.
Quaint? Can't imagine why.
She smiles.
Where's the nearest telephone?
Telephone? The Gunthers across the  valley. They're Mennonite. They have  cars and refrigerators and telephones  in the houses even.
No. I'd want a public phone.
Rachel's face clouds.
Well... the store at Saltzburg... (then briskly) But you won't be going to Saltzburg  for a while.
I'm going this morning.
But Stoltzfus said...
(cutting in) I know what he said.
You can go with Eli. He's taking  Samuel to school. But you'll have to  hurry.
Rachel turns to leave when Book calls her back.
Rachel.
She turns to look at him. It's the first time he's used h name.
Thanks.
She smiles and leaves.
Eli calls impatiently from the buggy. Samuel sits beside  him.
Hurry up now, John Book!

Rachel washing dishes turns on hearing Book enter. She la out loud at the sight of him in his Amish gear, and right so  the pants are highwater, the hat low-rise, the jacket ill-fitting. Book looks self-conscious, even a little sheepish. Outside another SHOUT from Eli.
You'd better go.
Book looks embarrassed.
My... eh... gun?

The smile fades from Rachel's face as she reaches up into cupboard. She passes the gun in its holster to Book. He  fastens it about him. The contradiction of an "Armed Amis increases the awkwardness between them. Book turns his ba to her and checks the weapon. He turns back to her smilin in an odd way.
The... bullets?
Oh. The bullets.
She takes them out of a disused coffee jar, passes them t Book.
(attempting a joke) Not much good without them.
Samuel sits between Eli and Book. Both men stare straight ahead. Eli looks particularly stern. It's pretty clear he doesn' like this Englishman wearing the clothes of his faith.
With awave Samuel runs into the schoolyard to join his  friends. A teacher begins ringing a bell.

Book on the telephone waiting for his call to be answered He looks about him  several Amish and Dithers mingle in t shop. Book-has gotten a coke from a machine, seems a bit self- conscious shout it sips at it surreptitiously... A voice  comes on the line; it's that of Book's partner.
Yeah?
A silence.
It's me.
Johnny! Where the hell have you been?
Never mind. I'm coming in to take  care of business. How hot am I?
(low, urgent) Too hot. Don't do it. Don't come in.
I'm coming.
Listen, Johnny, don't do anything  stupid. You couldn't get within a  mile of Schaeffer right now. So stay  put... Stay in touch  I'll let you  know when maybe it makes sense.
A beat as Book considers that.
(edgily) You hear me?
(finally) I hear you. I'll stay in touch.
That's more like it. (and) Where are you at, anyway?
Book allows himself a small smile, regarding his Amish im reflected in the window of the store.
Where I'm at is maybe 1890.
(uncomprehending) Say again?
Make that 1790.
He hangs up. A beat, then he stares toward the door of th store.

Book works on his car. The battery has gone flat and he's trying to charge it up by running wires to a battery moun under the front seat of the Lapp buggy. Eli stands at the barn door staring at him, again the  disapproving look.
If you are well enough to do that  thing, you can do work for me.
Book is genuinely apologetic.
Sure, I'm sorry. Hope you don't mind  me plugging in to your battery. Mine's  dead... How can I help? What can I  do?
Maybe milking.
(eyes Eli) Milking?
Cows. You know, cows?
I've seen pictures.
Good, you start tomorrow.

head_text.subj: INT. BOOK'S ROOM LAPP FARM NIGHT

text: Where Book lies asleep. A beat, then Eli comes in carryin lamp. He pauses a moment to peer at the sleeping figure with  undisguised anticipation. Then he gives him a jarring thu
(briskly) Veck oufl. Time for milking.
Book comes groggily awake as Eli exits. He gropes for his watch.
It reads 4:30 a.m.
As he stares at it in disbelief.
As the milk herd of half dozen or so cows ambles in with  Samuel prodding them along, headed for the milking stalls Book looks on in the lamplight, nonplused.
Where he's pitching hay into the cow's feed-troughs.
Where the old man is showing Book how to milk a cow by ha We see Rachel watching from the milkhouse door (steam fro scalding milk cans rising behind her).
Good, firm twist and pull, eh? (and) Right. Now you try it.
Book gives him a look, takes over the milking stool. The shoots him a rather skeptical look over her shoulder. Boo bends to his task.
Didn't you hear me, Book? Pull! You  never had your hands on a teat before?
(grimly) Not one this big.
Eli unexpectedly finds this hilarious, cackles, gives Boo comradely, man-of-the-world thump on the shoulder that ja him. Then he moves off. Book bends to his task, and...
Grinning, giggling, covering her mouth with one hand. As he pours a pail full of milk into a large, stainless s milk can.
As the milk herd is released back into the pasture. Book  crosses into the f.g., stares OFF SCREEN.
And dawnfire etching the hilltops. The BELLHOUSE behind t house, the sun reflecting from the heavy bell beneath its small roof.
Something in him can't help but respond to the beauty. A beat, then he blows on his hands, rubs them briskly tog against the morning chill, and turns back to the barn.
It is later in the morning. Rachel comes out onto the por tosses a pan of dirty dishwater off onto the grass, looks toward the barn.
Eli and Book standing in one of the open doorways, lookin in.

ANGLE FAVORING Luke, one of Eli's team of fine mules as S opens the stall gate. The beast is skittish, obviously  afflicted with something of a behavioral problem. But he allows Samuel to lead him out.
As Samuel brings Luke out. Eli is now harnessing the othe mule of the team to a large manure-spreader. But as Luke  nears Book, his eyes widen and he shies, almost hauling S off his feet.
(alarmed) Careful, son

Book moves to Samuel's aid; a gesture which proves a seri mistake. Luke erupts into a SCREAMING, bucking cyclone. S who no doubt has been here before  dives nimbly for cover as a flying hoof nearly takes Book's head off. Then Eli hustles into the fray, pushing Book aside as he  BELLOWS belligerently in German at the rearing animal. Fi he gives Luke a swat upside the head that seems, somehow, have the effect of quieting the beast instantly.
Samuel gives the shaken Book a look:
That's Luke. He doesn't like  strangers.
(still shaken) You don't say.
Eli leads the pacified mule back to the traces, grunting Book.
Have to teach you mules, too, I guess.

Book collects the pieces of the birdhouse which his car  knocked down the day of his attempted departure. He pause as a figure approaches. We recognize Daniel Hochstetler,  Rachel's would-be suitor. He heads for Book with an outgo smile and outstretched hand. Here's a likable man who lik people.
Good morning. Book, is it? You are  the Yankee they talk about?
I thought I was the English.
English, Yankee. It's the same. My  name is Daniel. Daniel Hochstetler. (sizes up his clothes) You look plain, Book. (grinning) Very plain.
Book is not particularly amused.
I came to see Rachel Lapp.
Try the house.
Hochstetler gives Book a powerful clap on the shoulder.
(genially) You bet. you take care of yourself.
Hochstetler heads for the house. Book stares after him wi some interest.

As Rachel emerges from the house to greet him. She also  catches sight of Book and she pauses, a shadow of confusi crossing her expression for an instant. And Hochstetler doesn't miss it either. Then she gives her suitor a genuine smile of welcome.
Book, having gathered up the pieces of the bird house, is headed toward the outbuildings, passing by hog pens. He  glances toward the house:
Where Rachel and Hochstetler are sitting in a porch swing sharing a pitcher of lemonade.
Thoughtful... He glances at the hog pen as a huge sow SQU and angrily noses her young ones away from the trough so can feed.
Pigs.

head_text.subj: INT. CARPENTRY SHOP, LAPP FARM DAY

text: Book works on repairing the broken birdhouse when Rachel  enters.
He uses a drawknife on a piece of 2x4, with some obvious  expertise.
Eli is a fine carpenter. Best in the  district. He and his father built  the big house themselves forty years  ago.
Oh? (and) What happened to Hochstetler?
We had some lemonade and he left.
A real fireball.
Rachel smiles. Book crosses to a workbench and selects an tool.
You know carpentry?
I did some carpentry summers when I  was going to school.
What else can you do?
(really annoyed) I can whack people. I'm hell at  whacking.
Whacking is not of much use on a  farm.
Now hold on. There's a lot of people  who think being a cop is a legitimate  job.
I'm sorry. I'm sure it is.
She turns, starts to go. Then turns back, eyeing his make garb:
Tonight I'll let out those trousers  for you.
Stifling a smile, she goes. HOLD on Book a beat, then...
Eli is seated at the head of the table, Book opposite Sam and Rachel. The table is piled high with an incredible am of food. Eli eyes Book cagily, waves his fork at him:
Eat up, Book. What's the matter with  your appetite?
Guess I'm not used to so much.
(snorts) Not used to hard work. That's what  makes an appetite.
Book swallows that one. With difficulty. Rachel intervene
Eli, John is a carpenter. (conciliatory  afterthought) As well as being a fine policeman.
Eh? Well then, maybe he can go to  Zook's barn-raising, eh? See how  good a carpenter.
Book can't refuse the challenge.
Sure.
But... You may not be well enough.
I'll drink some more of Stoltzfus'  tea.
As Rachel, lamp in hand, walks up to the barn. She looks to find Book tinkering with the battery hookup to the Lap buggy. He glances up as she enters:
Hi...
As she sets her lamp down near the one he's using.
(beat) When will you be going?
Not long... A few days.

Another beat as Rachel watches him... Book, checking out battery power, hits the radio  and suddenly from the  Twentieth Century comes the sound of one of its major  inventions  rock and roll. It fills the barn, but Book turns up the volume a click m even and, eyeing Rachel, starts moving with the beat. It' his culture, coming through loud and clear, as incongruou as it all might seem with the tough Philly cop decked out Amish. Rachel can't help but laugh... Sensing her response, Book sweeps her up and they boogie in the lamplight, Rachel  alternately protesting and laughing.
You like it... Don't you?
Rachel, confused, protests:
No... You just stop
But she doesn't really want to. Book grins:
(mock alarm) Next thing you know you'll be off  drinking beer and racing motorcycles.
And it goes on... Rachel alternately protesting and laugh
As Eli suddenly appears. He glowers for an instant,  thunderstruck, then BELLOWS:
Rachel!
As Book and Rachel's dancing comes to a sudden halt. Both turn, look at Eli. Rachel regards him level-eyed, without discernible alarm. Book, looking a bit sheepish, goes ove turns off the radio, as:
(in the dialect) What is this? This Myusick?
Book hesitates, then starts to say something:
It's not her fault. I
But he gets such a look from Eli that he turns, goes out.
(in the dialect) How can this be? How can you do such  a thing? Is this plain? Is this the  ordnung?
I have done nothing against the  ordnung.

(in the dialect) Eh? Nothing? Rachel, you bring this  man to our house. With his gun of  the hand. You bring fear to this  house. Fear of English with guns  coming after. You bring blood and  whispers of more blood. Now English  music... and you are dancing to  English music! And you call this  nothing?
I have committed no sin.

(in English) No sin? Maybe. Not yet. But, Rachel,  it does not look... (tone softening... in  the dialect) Don't you know there has been talk?  Talk about you, not him. Talk about  going to the Bishop. About having  you... shunned!
That is idle talk.

(in English, pleading) Do not make light of it, Rachel.  They can do it... quick! Like that!  And then... then I can not sit at  table with you. I can not take a  thing from your hand. I... I can not  go with you to meeting! (the old man almost  breaks down as, in  the dialect) Rachel, good Rachel, you must not go  too far! Dear child!
Rachel is annoyed  also touched, no doubt, by the old man plea  but irked by his condescending tone.
I am not a child.
(suddenly stern again) You are acting like one!
I will be the judge of that.
(fierce as a prophet) No! They will be the judge of that!  And so will I... if you shame me!
(blinking a tear now,  but meeting his gaze) You shame yourself.
And shaken  but proud and erect  she turns and walks out.
Carter sits, Schaeffer prowls... slowly, letting silences grow before he strikes again with another softly-snarled  question or statement.
You know where he is.
Wrong.
You'd lie to protect him.
(cool) Probably.
Schaeffer snaps around, glares at him.
You admit you're lying?
(shakes head) I admit I don't know where he is.
You're the first one he'll contact.
(sighing) He's got my number.
Schaeffer stops, stands in front of Carter, takes a deep  breath... suddenly smiles. And is abruptly (as he is capa of being) the man of charm and gentlemanly reason. He eve CHUCKLES as he begins:
It's funny. I know he's hiding  somewhere with the Amish, I know it. (a quick glance at  Carter) Can you imagine John Book at a prayer  meeting? Our John Book?
Schaeffer CHUCKLES again, looks hopefully again at Carter Carter looks back, stony-eyed. Schaeffer makes another ab shift in form... but still speaks softly.
Either you're a member of the club  or you aren't, Elton. (he nods his head, as) Tell me what you know...
What I know, Paul, is... (nodding his head) He's going to take you out...

head_text.subj: EXT. LAPP FARM LANCASTER COUNTY DAY

text: As Book pauses by the barn door, glances over his shoulde
With trace horse harnessed... Samuel and Eli loading  provisions into the buggy, standing down by the house.

head_text.subj: BACK TO BOOK INT. / EXT. BARN

text: As he goes into the barn. Book approaches Luke's stall warily... and as he does so temperamental mule, reacting to form, starts to skitter, hooves CRACKING against the walls of the stall. Book flin Book starts to talk gently to the animal:
All right, you nasty son of a bitch,  we're going to be friends whether  you like it or not.
Then, summoning his resolve, he carefully opens the stall gate.
As Luke eyes him balefully, Book reaches into his pocket, brings out some lumps of sugar.
See... Sugar. You like sugar, don't  you for Christ's sake?
Finally, keeping a mistrustful eye on Book, Luke condesce to eat. Book nods with satisfaction.
Rachel has entered the barn, is watching Book with a puzz expression.
(surprised) Well...
Book turns, grins with some pride of accomplishment!
Won him over just like that.
I see. (and) But I hope you have a lot of sugar. (then, going) Eli is ready to go to Zook's.
Just then Luke skitters impatiently... Book gives him a  nervous look; one last tentative pat as Luke eyes him  skeptically, then closes the stall gate and turns to go:
Later.
And we...

head_text.subj: EXT. ZOOK FARM LANCASTER COUNTY DAY

text: BIG SHOT... it's early morning as the Amish buggies are  arriving at the Zook farm for a barn-raising. In the b.g. we can see big stacks of lumber all around th construction site where a couple of dozen men have begun  raising the main supports on the already laid foundation. Elsewhere, long tables have been set up and women are  spreading them with cloths, setting out big tanks of hot  coffee and cold lemonade for the men,
As Eli, Book, Rachel and Samuel step down, Book eyes the  construction site.
Wait here 'til I find a gang you can  work with.
He goes. Book glances around as even more buggies arrive more workmen and their families climb out. Eli appears with Hochstetler in tow. Hochstetler's broad  face breaks into a grin:
Book! Good to see you!

He pumps Book's hand with his usual vigor, smiling a gree and pleasantry to Rachel. She looks on, amused. Hochstetler gives Rachel a look, and we realize that his  showing up just now to appropriate Book was no happenstan And Book realizes it as well.
Eli says you're a carpenter, Book.
It's been a while.
No matter. Come with me. We can always  use a good carpenter.
With that he throws a huge arm around Book's shoulder and ushers him away. Rachel calls after them:
Good luck.
As they move off.
Your hole is healed, then?
(gives him a look) Pretty much.
Hochstetler nods with satisfaction:
Good. Then you can go home.

As the morning progresses: ...Book and Hochstetler sawing and augering out heavy tim on big sawhorses. There's an unmistakable atmosphere of  competition between the two men, which doesn't go entirel unnoticed by the half-dozen or so other young men on the  gang. ...or, indeed, by Rachel; in fact, she seems  without lea on it too heavily  to be measuring the two men as the mor progresses, and she occasionally passes within proximity them. ...Eli and a couple of other elders prowling the job with sheaves of hand-drawn sketches under their arms, supervis the construction. All around them the structure is rising with remarkable rapidity. ...Rachel, where she's helping the women set out the huge noon meal. Other women are sitting on benches in the b.g. knitting or doing quiltwork. ...Samuel, where he's banging away with a hammer, with a  group of boys his own age. Elsewhere we see little girls  "botching" (a hand-clapping game played to German rhymes) ...The very elderly; sitting on the grass or in wheelchai in the sunlight, looking on  the old men kibitzing in Ger the women gossiping. Until...

Of the barn-raising with the noon sun high overhead... at least a hundred and fifty men are swarming over and about the barn framework... ...some aid the rafters, some hauling lumber to the job,  others sawing, hammering, drilling, joining, planing and  what-all... so many that the barn seems almost to be rear up before our very eyes. And there isn't a power tool in  sight.

As Rachel crosses near the benches... we can see other wo eyeing her, whispering among themselves, some tittering.  Rachel ignores them. She joins the stoutly amiable Mrs. Yoder from the funeral sequence earlier. The older woman is emptying a big pan o fried chicken into serving platters. She smiles, obviousl liking Rachel.
Everyone has an idea about you and  the English.
All of them charitable, I'm sure.
Hardly any of them.

Book and Hochstetler astride the roofbeam studs, holding  them together prior to nailing them to the roof-beam. The are, therefore, crotch to the mast and facing one another way out at the far end of the roof. Suddenly, as Hochstetler raises his hammer, the studs sta to part, threatening to de-ball the both of them. Hochstetler drops his hammer, grabs both sides of the roo with incredible brute strength, and, literally, pulls it  back together. Book stares at Hochstetler with nothing short of awe. Hochstetler, straining and grinning, looks to Book:
Nail it!
Yes, sir.
And he does nail it while Hochstetler, grinning and holdi looks on.
The barn is done, the workmen climbing down from the raft It's late afternoon.

He hesitates. His face is pale and covered with sweat. Th exertion of the day has taken its toll. He's in danger of fainting and is some forty feet above the ground. But he' determined it won't happen, determined that he won't fall nor will he humiliate himself by calling for help. Hochst guesses the situation. He moves beside Book, claps an arm about him, says nothing, doesn't even look at Book. From  below, someone TELLS them to hurry up. Hochstetler shouts:
We admire our work!

The moment passes for Book, and he's okay. Hochstetler re his supporting arm. Book looks him in the eye, nods his  appreciation almost imperceptibly. Hochstetler wants no  thanks, and Book knows it. Hochstetler gives him a resoun SLAP on the back, and starts climbing down. Book follows.

head_text.subj: EXT. ZOOK FARM LANCASTER COUNTY EVENING

text: The gathering has congregated to hear Bishop Tschantz off up a blessing on the new barn.

PANNING the faces as they listen to the heavy German word rolling out over the still evening air. Book stands a little to one side of the Amish. The prayer he cannot share with them. Rachel is aware of this, feels something of his emotion. She looks toward him, then she closes her eyes and drifts away from him, into the soothi prayer.
Book stands outside, listening to the NIGHT SOUNDS. He tu walks up toward the porch.
Book takes a seat in a chair, SIGHS, looks toward the nig sky. There is a SOUND, but it's a moment before he turns his e toward the door.
Samuel standing there in his nightshirt.
As Book leans forward in his chair.
Hey, Sam...
...I want to say a thing.
(sitting up) What's that, Sam?
The boy hesitates, holds for a time, then suddenly darts  across to Book, wraps his arms around him, hugs him tight then breaks away, turns and runs hack into the house, lea the door open behind him.
Looking after the boy, genuinely moved. After a moment, h speaks softly:
Same to you, Sam.
After another moment, he gets up, moves to close the door that Samuel has left open behind him.
