From the lighted/shadowed area outside the door. He comes the door, starts to close it, then hesitates, looks into where the light is coming from. He looks down the corrido The light is obviously coming from the kitchen. He speaks softly:
Sam?
No answer. Book steps inside, pulls the door shut behind  him, moves down-the corridor toward the kitchen.

Where Rachel, dressed only in a plain cotton camisole, is pouring a pail of steaming water into a tub. She replaces the pail on the stove, turns and slips out o her camisole. Naked, she folds the garment across the bac of a chair. Then she pauses, containing a startled intake of breath.
The gleaming bottom of a large copper skillet hanging ove the stove with other cookware, we can see Book's image  reflected there, framed in the kitchen doorway.

Rachel hesitates for a moment  and in that moment she mak a choice. Slowly she turns, to face him, without shame, meeting his eyes. And for a moment she attempts something: a look, a flash eve... a lovely, heartbreakingly innocent effort to becom for an instant, a woman of Book's world.

As he stands in the doorway, willing himself to leave, un to make it happen. And suddenly the moment has passed. Rachel lowers her eye picks up the camisole, covers herself with it without put it on, looks away.
TIGHTENING to him, and...

Where Rachel is scattering feed to the chickens. A beat, then Book approaches from behind her. A moment, a she senses his presence. Book watches as Rachel begins to gather the eggs, placing them in the fold of her apron. When he speaks, he speaks softly, and she pauses in her w
Last night.
She goes very still, but keeps her back to him.
If... we'd made love, then, I couldn't  leave.
She lowers her head slightly, but remains turned away fro him. Book continues to stare at her.

head_text.subj: EXT. RURAL ROAD LANCASTER COUNTY DAY

text: The Lapp carriage on a winding lane.

Rachel is driving, Book sitting next to her. Samuel is in the back, looking out the rear window and not paying any  attention to the adults. A beat, then a large produce truck roars past them. It's Book can do to keep from flinching. Rachel stares straight ahead. Book glances at her.
Maybe I ought to learn to drive this  thing.
Rachel says nothing.
(beat) Pick myself up another useful skill.
Now Rachel can't help but smile. She looks at him. And...
We can see the Lapp buggy approaching a rural intersectio another buggy approaching at right angles.
As Rachel eyes the other buggy through the windshield.
Samuel, who is that?
Samuel checks out the buggy.
It looks like Hochstetler's mare.
As the Lapp buggy passes the intersection and the Hochste buggy swings in behind them. Then the Hochstetler buggy,  coming on at a faster clip, starts to pass the Lapp buggy
As Rachel waves at the occupants of the other buggy; Dani returns her greeting:
(teasing her) Uh oh, they're leaving us behind.
Rachel gives him a look, and... gives the reins a flick   the race is on.

Hochstetler has a couple of older folk on board, together with his young sister  at first they're not aware of the  race, until Daniel can contain his excitement no longer a gives his horse a couple of whoops. The buggies are neck neck, and the older people are not protesting loudly. It's all Book can do to refrain from grabbing the reins o Rachel, but she's something of a horsewoman and finally s gains the edge and pulls ahead of Hochstetler, to the che of Samuel and Book.

It's a Saturday afternoon in the tourist season, and they everywhere  taking shots of anything Amish. There's a ROW YOUNG ELEMENT amongst them who are making their presence  fast, and generally making a nuisance of themselves. Book and Rachel get out of the buggy. Samuel stays inside the crowds make him nervous. A huge tourist bus billowing smoke pulls up nearby. Rachel enters the store, but before Book can follow he's  stopped by a TOURIST LADY with an instamatic camera... Sh waggles the camera at him...
Could I... ah, you know?
(smiling) Lady, if you take my picture, I'll  rip your brassiere off and strangle  you with it.
The Tourist Lady stares at him in stunned disbelief, her  grin frozen on her face. Then she begins to scuttle back  from whence she came.

Rachel is browsing among the stocked shelves in the compa of a young Amish woman, Ellie Beiler. Rachel is carrying  Ellie's tiny baby, and the infant is getting as much atte as the shopping. Book is standing at a wall pay phone in the b.g. We TIGHT to him, and...
Lieutenant Elton Carter, please.
A beat, then we hear the FILTERED VOICE of the Philadelph Police Department switchboard:
Are you a member of the family?
What? I'm a friend of his.
I'm sorry. Last night Sergeant Carter  was killed in the line of duty...

Book hangs up. His breathing is thrown out by the shock o the news and he takes a couple of deep breaths to regain  control. He hesitates, unsure of his next move. He makes move away, then he turns back, finds more coins and dials second number.
Schaeffer's wife answers the phone; she is momentarily  shocked. She calls for her husband, then makes polite conversation
How are you, John?
Paul Schaeffer appears, slightly irritated at being calle away from the Saturday afternoon game.
(covering mouthpiece) John Book!
I'll take it in the study.
Schaeffer takes the phone.
You can hang up, dear.
We HEAR the click of the other phone,
You made a mistake, Paul. You  shouldn't have taken Elton out.
(beat) How bad did Mac get you? We figured  pretty bad.
I'm fine. I'm going to live a long  time. That's what I called to tell  you.
(quickly) Johnny
You might want to pass it along to  Mac.
(urgently) Listen to me, Johnny. Come in! You're  out there all alone... We're getting  close... real close... Maybe if you  listen to me for a minute we can  work something out so you can come  in
I've already got something worked  out. (and) Be seeing you.

Book hangs up the phone and the dead CLICK registers on  Schaeffer. Book has gripped the phone so tightly that it takes a sec to unclench his fist. Then it takes something else to res his first impulse, which is to smash out at something...  Training. Get it under control. Deal rationally with the  situation. He straightens his jacket, wipes the sweat/tears from his eyes, turns and walks stiffly out of the Saltzburg Genera Store.

head_text.subj: INT. BUGGY MAIN STREET SALTZBURG DAY

text: Book, as Rachel eyes him. She has noticed his changed moo but doesn't ask about it. He stares straight ahead, obliv to the surroundings of the street, now crawling with tour and traffic.

head_text.subj: EXT. NARROW SIDE STREET SALTZBURG DAY

text: The buggy turns into the side street. Some hundred yards  ahead another buggy is stopped in the middle of the road several youths gathered about it. A pickup truck is stopp facing the buggy.
As Rachel approaches the scene, slowing down and finally  stopping. Rachel is at first puzzled, then makes a small face, look at Book. Rachel puts a restraining hand on Book's arm.
Do nothing. This happens from time  to time.
She senses him about to get out, grips his arm tightly.
It's not our way, John. We'll have  nothing to do with violence! John!
Book shakes free, gets out and slowly walks toward the...

Hochstetler and his family sit, impassive, ignoring vario jeers and taunts from the English lads  various jokes abo them being dirty etc. One jabs an ice cream cone into  Hochstetler's forehead, which leaves a curious white circ on his forehead. Another fools about with the horse causi it to shy. A third notices the slow, sure, approach of Jo Book.
Here comes another one!
Book stops, his path blocked by the third youth. The yout flicks off Book's hat.
(quietly) You're making a mistake.
Hochstetler calls from his buggy.
Everything is all right, John.
(to the youth) Pick up the hat.

The youth momentarily unsure  something about Book's tone of voice. The youth does pick up the hat, crumples it, st on it, and puts it back at a crazy angle on Book's head. pause, then Book explodes. The kid never knew what hit him or where it came from, he hits the road surface already unconscious. A second youth grabs Book from behind. A mistake. Book is smashing into  him, spatters of blood from his nose flying in all direct He's hitting too hard, too often. It's Schaeffer he's hit Hochstetler is pulling him away, Rachel is there too. A c is gathering, but as suddenly as it began it's over. Book shakes Hochstetler off him, straightens his hat, and in a kind of daze, begins walking past the scene in the direct of the Lapp farm. The youths are picking up their wounded, helping them bac to their truck, aided by none other than Hochstetler. An LOCAL addresses Rachel.
Never seen anything like that in all  my years.
(covering) He's from... Ohio... My cousin.
We'll, them Ohio Amish sure must be  different. (addresses a gathering  crow) Our Lancaster brethren, they just  don't have that kind of fight in  them.
John, lost control of himself. He...  will be repentant.
(to Rachel) You're Rachel Lapp, aren't you?
Yes. Samuel! We're going.
A second man calls from the pickup.
Kid's nose is broken!
We'll take him up the hospital. Good- day to you, Mrs. Lapp. (he shouts after her) This ain't good for the tourist trade,  you know! You tell that to your Ohio  cousin!
But Rachel is already steering past the scene and followi the by now distant figure of John Book.
Book comes out of the carpenter's shop carrying the repai birdhouse on its pole in one hand, a shovel in the other. Rachel is shepherding the milking cows toward the barn.
You should not bother with that  birdhouse. (a beat) If you're leaving tomorrow.
I'm leaving tonight. (and) I'm going to need my clothes. And my  gun.
She nods, looks away... looks back at him twice in glance There is a moment when it appears she might either bark a him or begin to weep. He waits. When she does turn to him she speaks softly:
There was a time when I thought you  might have stayed.
(hesitating... then) There was.
There was a time when I would have  welcomed it.
(after a beat) I know.
(asking) I was being foolish?
No. (and) I was being unrealistic. Even thinking  about living this life.
You're so sure of that?
Aren't you? After today?

(almost conceding it,  but... her voice  rising a bit, annoyed) I'm not so sure of anything as you  are, John Book. You could live this  life if you wanted to bad enough. (a beat) Just as I could live yours!
(almost groaning) Oh, come on, Rachel. No way.
There is always a way! But you are  such a... a Glotzkopp you cannot  see! You'd rather go back to that  city! To nothing! No woman! No  children! No land!
(now getting annoyed) Land! Are you crazy? I'm no Amishman  and I'm no farmer! I'm a cop. That's  what I know and that's what I do!
What you do is take vengeance! Which  is a sin against heaven!
That's your way, not mine.
That's God's way!
Well in the City of Philadelphia,  God needs a little help!

He has offended her, immediately knows it, but can't brin himself to make an instant apology. But he's chewing on i when she takes the moment unto herself. She pulls herself up, speaks with great dignity:
I could never love a man who was  so... little.

He looks at her, sad-eyed, his anger ebbing and gone,  realizing that he'll never meet a finer woman... never ev get close to such a one. He appears to start to speak, bu then does not. She turns, moves away a few steps, stops, looks back at h she holds for a moment, blinking tears, then speaks with  some difficulty, emotion welling in her words.

The other night... when you saw me  after my bath... I... I tried to  look as I thought you would want a  woman to look. (sadly... but with a  slight, proud lift  of chin) I am sorry... that I did not.
She holds for an instant, then turns and walks off.
Looking after her. A face full of loss.
Eli is lighting the lamps. Samuel reads a book at the kit table. Rachel moves slowly to the sink and begins washing few dishes. She looks out the window. CLOSE on her face, a strange expression.
The distant figure of Book working on the birdhouse.

CLOSE on Rachel's hands, lifting items slowly up and of t water to the draining board, where she places them carefu down. She shakes the water off her hands. CLOSE on her face, still staring fixedly out the window. speaks without turning around.
Eli, would you see Samuel to bed?
The old man glances at her; this is not their routine.
In the rapidly fading light, Rachel walks slowly toward B CLOSE on her face, staring straight ahead toward Book. ANGLE on Book, CLOSE. He turns and watches Rachel's appro
The light now nearly gone, the NIGHT SOUNDS beginning, as Rachel reaches Book and they embrace.
Book and Rachel in a passionate embrace, sink to the stil warm earth and make love.

head_text.subj: EXT. SOUDERSBURG CAFE LANCASTER COUNTY NIGHT

text: ESTABLISHING an all-night cafe in the early hours of the  morning. TIGHTENING to the bleakly lighted windows.

A booth, where Schaeffer and McElroy and Fergie, a Lancas County Undersheriff and his SHERIFF  an expansive politic type  are seated. The Undersheriff eyes Schaeffer narrowly. The Sheriff has county map spread out on the table, amid breakfast dishes pointing directions to Schaeffer:
There... White Oak Road a couple of  miles before it ties into two-twenty- two. Got it?
Got it. We owe you one, Sheriff.
My man Holmes here put it together.  Fine officer, Chief. He spoke to the  doctor at the hospital.
Undersheriff Holmes and I have talked  on the phone. (nods at Holmes) Good work.
Sure you don't want us to post some  backup units?
If we need any help, we'll give you  a shout. I'd like to slip in there  quiet, then get out before we attract  any attention.
As Schaeffer and his men are climbing into their car. Hol and the Sheriff watch after them.
Maybe I'll take a drive over that  way.
Let 'em be. It's their dirty laundry.
But Holmes pauses to watch Schaeffer's car pull out.

head_text.subj: EXT. RURAL LANE LANCASTER COUNTY DAWN

text: With the first light of dawn on the eastern horizon,  Schaeffer's car approaches along the lane, pulls into the Lapp driveway and comes to a halt. In the b.g. we can make out the farmhouse and outbuilding HOLD as Schaeffer, McElroy and Fergie step out of the car They break out short-barreled twelve-gauge pumps, start T CAMERA, spreading out as they turn up the long driveway.. figures of ominous intent striding through the misty dawn
GOING WITH the trio of gunmen... McElroy, breath smoking the chill, eyes the terrain:
Weird, man. No fuckin' electricity.  What do you figure they plug all  their shit into?
They don't have any shit.
Where Eli is getting into a heavy coat, preparing to go o the remains of the hearty morning breakfast are on the ta Rachel is beginning the dishes.
Book and Samuel are starting the morning milking...

Eli is preparing to extinguish the lamp when suddenly the kitchen door is kicked open and McElroy and Fergie weapon leveled, burst in. Eli reacts with angry shock as Schaeff enters: Rachel is, for a moment, terrified.
(to Fergie) Outside  (to Mac) Check out the rest of the house.
He turns to Eli, who is standing in the middle of the roo Schaeffer flashes his badge:
We're police officers. We're looking  for a fugitive, John Book. He's living  here?
I have nothing to say to you. Get  out of my house!
You speak English. Good. Now listen
(recovering) No, you listen. Get out!
Lady, I'm here to help you. This man  is very dangerous. An armed criminal. (ingratiating) He's got a gun, hasn't he?
You have no right here!
McElroy re-enters.
He's not in this building.
(to Eli) All right, where is he?
Suddenly Eli SHOUTS: It's deafening. Probably the loudest noise Eli has ever made:
John Book!
McElroy whips around, smashes Eli on the temple with the  butt of his shotgun. Eli crumples to the floor. Rachel  SCREAMS, runs to Eli.
Book and Samuel in the milkhouse. They've heard Eli's out Book moves to the window, looks out.
About halfway between the barn and the house. He turns fr glancing back toward the house (having heard Eli's shout) and starts again toward the barn. Gun at the ready.
As Book REACTS.
Rachel kneeling next to Eli, wiping at his bruise with a  damp cloth. Schaeffer looks on.
He'll live.
You might have killed him!
(to McElroy) Find Fergie, check the barns. I'll  watch these two.
McElroy nods, moves outside, turns toward the barns.
Book still at the window, Samuel now beside him, trying t get a look.
Is it them?
(turning, mind racing) It's them, Sam. (he bends to the boy,  takes him by the  shoulders) Now, Sam, listen to me and listen to  me carefully. Listen to me as you  never listened before.
(interrupting) Are they going to kill you?
Listen to me, Sam! I want you to go  across the new corn to Stoltzfus'.  Run as fast as you can. And stay  there!
What are you going to do?
I'll be all right. You just do as I  say.
He takes Samuel by the hand, leads him to the side door. bends, holds the boy close.
Don't let them hurt you.
(rising, pushing Samuel  toward door) I won't. Now run. (as Sam looks back) Fast as you can!
Sam turns, takes off.
Samuel running.
Fergie almost to the upper barn, McElroy  well back and  moving slowly, circumspectly  headed toward the lower bar
Book, at another window in the lower barn, sees McElroy  heading for the milkhouse door. He can't see Fergie. He t crosses the cowpen area, climbs an inner ladder leading t the upper barn.
Fergie at the door to the upper barn, moving very cautiou gun up. He eases around the doorpost, looks within.

Beyond Book, now at the top of the ladder, we see Fergie  easing into the barn. Book pulls himself up, crawls behin the wall of the mule stalls, opens gate, eases in beside  Luke, urgently whispering and patting the animal to calm  him. He gets to the animal's head, crouches, strokes Luke nose. The mule's huge flanks quiver, his nostril's and ey widen, but he makes no untoward sound. Book closes the ga
He comes on warily, muzzle first, eyes darting. DOLLYING WITH him as he reaches the first mule's stall, o the gate. An edgy mule turns, eyes him, shuffles nervousl Fergie backs off, moves on.
As he listens, tenses, hearing Fergie's feet in the fresh straw. Book eases back alongside Luke, waits.
As he approaches Luke's stall, reaches for the gate-latch
As the gate swings open, Book shouts and gives Luke a wha on the back. The mule's pent-up nerves and feral energy  explode in an horrendous SCREAM.

Bowled backwards by the rearing animal as the gate flies  open, involuntarily FIRING, suddenly finding himself unde the lethal hooves of a twelve-hundred pound beast. Stagge backwards, he SCREAMS, FIRES again, the load striking the mule in its heaving chest as a flailing hoof smashes into Fergie's head and the other hoof snaps his shotgun in hal like a matchstick.
As he slips out of the stall, ducks toward the rear of th barn.
Fallen, skull smashed... and now the dying Luke's legs bu and he collapses atop Fergie.
McElroy standing still, shock-eyed, looking toward the so of the shots. Then starting slowly forward.
On the porch of the house, looking toward the barn.
Some distance from the barn, Samuel's hearing the shots,  stops dead in his tracks... the sound of the shots still  REVERBERATING across the quiet fields.
(stricken) Mr. Book?
He hesitates, then turns, starts trotting back toward the barns.
Rachel has moved into the open kitchen door, glances anxi toward the barns. Starts out. Schaeffer pushes her back.
Get back in there.
My son is out there!
Nobody's going to hurt your son...
As McElroy, checking the safety on his twelve-gauge, step into the barn.
McElroy flattens himself against the wall, looks around  fearfully.
(softly) Fergie?
Only silence.
Schaeffer staring toward the barn, SHOUTS:
What the hell happened?
He listens, hears nothing, snorts, starts toward the barn checking his gun, not hurrying.
Eli now seated at the table, holding a cloth to his head. Rachel at a window, peering out. Schaeffer on the porch
Samuel running as fast as he can trips as he crosses a sm muddy stream, falls full length, scrambles up, runs on.
McElroy, moving very cautiously, comes around the mule st stops short, stares off screen.
Where he lies half buried beneath the huge bulk of the mu his head crushed like an eggshell.
As he moves on around Fergie and the dead mule, planting  each foot as if he were walking in a mine field.
Standing in shadow at the back of the barn next to a hay  mow.
Moving toward the center of the barn.
As he starts to move even further back, he nudges into a  rope fastened to the wall behind him, He looks at it, loo up.

It runs from where it is fastened to the wall straight up the center roofbeam of the barn to a trolley fixed to a t that runs the length of the roofbeam. Attached to this tr is a big hayfork (Paul Krantz has one), U-shaped, sharply pointed at each end of the U. the points hanging toward t floor. The thing weighs about eighty pounds, and is suspe in place by the rope anchored at the wall next to Book.
Keeping one eye on McElroy, he carefully begins to un-tie the trip rope.

Moving out toward the center of the barn, almost under th suspended hay fork. He stops short, listens. Then, either spotting a moving shadow or hearing a SOUND, he FIRES. Hi shot rattles off the side of a manure spreader. He SHOUTS
Book, you sneaky bastard, I know  you're here! Come out and fight!

Samuel, at the top of the barnyard, stops at the SOUND OF THE SHOT, wide-eyed. He listens for an-instant, starts a  step toward the barn, then stops again, looks to a large  bell suspended in a cupola by one of the outbuildings. He moves quickly to the bell, seizes the rope, pulls. The be CLANGS loudly, Sonorously.
On the front porch, looking around for the location of th sounding bell. He takes a step toward the barn, the stops looks back toward the house... frustrated.
Book watches as McElroy starts to move again looking back toward the SOUNDING of the bell.
Looking down we can see McElroy almost directly beneath t hay fork. The bell SOUNDING throughout. BOOK Waiting... t rope in hand. Then:
(shouting) Hey, Mac!
And he lets go the trip rope.
As he turns toward the SOUND of Book's voice.
As it plummets down, causing a RATCHETING SOUND that fill the barn, even drowns out the SOUND of the bell.
Eyes darting wildly, looking up.
Plunging straight for him.
Diving to one side.
THUDDING into the barn floor like a great trident fork. Quivering there, not a foot from McElroy's head.
Staring at the fork pop-eyed.
Sprinting toward a ladder thrust up through an opening in the barn floor just in front of his parked car.
Spotting Book, coming up to one knee, quick-aiming, FIRIN The shot smashes the windshield of the car.
Diving, rolling, slamming into the top of the ladder, fla down out of sight.
FIRING AGAIN, then again. Emptying the gun, cursing as he begins to reload, gets to his feet, starts toward the lad The BELL still SOUNDING outside. The hood of the car SLOW POPS UP.
As McElroy wheels at the movement of the car's hood, FIRE twice.
The buckshot virtually blows the dashboard off.

Samuel RINGING the bell. The bell rope is short, and so i Samuel and his feet go off the ground with every swing of the rockerarm. He hangs on grimly, his black hat clinging to the back of his head, his face set against the tears that move down h cheeks.

Comes hesitantly down the path toward the barn, looking t the sound of the bell, but also looking back in glances t the house to make sure Rachel and Eli stay where they are He still can't see Samuel.
As Rachel starts off the porch, takes a few steps.
Turning, SHOUTING:
You stay put!
She stops. She is also unable to see Samuel.
Moving out toward the barn, rounding a corner... and ther is Samuel at the bellrope. He starts toward him.

Beyond Samuel, well out in the fields of the Stoltzfus fa Stotlzfus and others  including Hochstetler and his broth are baling the first cutting of June hay. But the operation has come to a halt. All are looking in  toward the Lapp farm, hearing the RINGING OF THE BELL (th Amish cry for help), wondering, hesitating. But now, as we watch, led by Hochstetler, they start in t Samuel.
As Schaeffer reaches Samuel, SHOUTS:
Cut that out!

Samuel looks at him, keeps on pulling. Schaeffer quickly crosses to him, grabs him by the back o the neck, tries to pull him off the bell rope. Samuel han on grimly. Schaeffer yanks hard, succeeds in yanking Samuel free, sh him roughly aside. Then Schaeffer turns, FIRES a shotgun  blast into the top of the bellrope. It still hangs by sev threads, so he FIRES again. The rope drops to the ground. Schaeffer reloads, turns to look at Samuel, just getting to his feet. A moment... whe Schaeffer, recognizing Samuel as the Amish kid who saw Mc kill Zenovich, perhaps thinks of disposing of the witness right then and there. But a glance toward the oncoming Amish gives him pause. H SNARLS at Sam:
Get down to the house and stay there!
Samuel gets to his feet, turns, trots off.
Already halfway out to the barn, running to gather Sam in her arms... then to lead him back toward the house.
Turning, starting very slowly toward the barn.
McElroy at the top of the ladder, looking down. Then easi over, placing his feet on the rungs.
He stands below in a cowpen, using the cows for cover. Th cows stare balefully at him. A large goat nuzzles him, ho at him with its horns. Book waits, watches.
Visible to his knees as he eases down the ladder. He stop at every rung to scrape his shoes free of the cowshit cov the rungs.
He turns now to a door at the back of the pen. He un-hook it, pulls it open, moves inside.

He is now in a small passageway giving on to the entrance a nearly-empty silo. Above the entrance, a ladder (interi rises to the top of the structure. Book looks in, and up. We should get the impression that  Book's been here before, expects what he sees.
Forty feet up, a patch of blue sky through an open hatch.
He steps through to the base of the ladder, then ducks be it into the silo. There is about two feet of old silage  covering the floor. He turns, looks up the white walls.
An inside ladder runs to the top.
Standing against the wall next to the entrance... . obvio to be inserted as the silo is filled.
Now, quickly, he ducks back out through the entrance, cro to the door to the cowpen, very cautiously peers out..
McElroy at the bottom of the ladder, looking in the other direction (toward the milkhouse).
Very carefully he shoves the cowpen door (which opens out into the cowpen). It begins to swing very slowly open. Bo immediately turns, darts back into the silo.

Turning slowly toward the cowpen... then FIRES twice as h eye catches the motion of the swinging door. His shots bl half a row of Eli's precious tools off an adjacent wall.  McElroy reloads, starts across toward the door.
Old Eli, at the sight of Samuel, rises from the table.
Praise Gott!

Rachel stands aside as the old man embraces Samuel long a hard. She watches as he turns to the cupboard, takes down the b family Bible. He crosses to the table, sets the book down places his hand on its pulls Samuel to the table beside h Rachel holds another beat as she stares at the old man  helplessly, then she rushes to where she hid Book's gun,  takes it down... her trembling hands take the bullets out the coffee jar. She drops several as she tries to figure how to open the chamber to load it. In the b.g., Eli glances up, sees what she is about... he rises and crosses to her. Samuel watches from the table.
(fiercely) No, Rachel...
I have to help him!
Rachel somehow manages to open the chamber and begins to to load the bullets. Eli's callused hand closes over hers halting the action:
It is not our way!

Bullets are already CLATTERING to the floor from her trem fingers as she raises her eyes to Eli's. A long beat as Rachel looks at him... Finally her fingers release the pistol and it CLATTERS to the floor. She clos her eyes. Samuel, who has gotten up, moved to a window, watches Eli and Rachel silently. Eli leads her to the table, places her hands on the Bible beneath his. They stand there and they pray.
Book finishes putting the kickboard into the entrance.

Moving among the cows, stepping cautiously between the  cowflops. The goat nudges him once, then butts him rather firmly.  McElroy swats at him with the gun butt, moves to the door As he arrives, he HEARS a noise  very slight  from the  direction of the silo. He enters the passage way, looks in toward the silo entra He hesitates. Another slight noise. He steps in to the ba of the inner ladder, looks up.
The patch of blue sky, forty feet up.
He frowns, reaches out, grabs a rung.

Schaeffer, easing toward the mule stalls, MUTTERS, CURSES under his breath. Then he rounds the corner of the first  stall... and there is Fergie with Luke the mule on top of him. Schaeffer stares, blinks... moves on spotting a spen shotgun shell near the hayfork...
Book listening at the kickboard. SOUNDS of feet, shotgun  rattling against metal rungs, Book moves to the ladder on his side, starts silently up.
Climbing with difficulty, shotgun clutched in one hand.
He climbs up to the second kickboard, pauses, checks the  distance to the floor, starts upward again.

The Amish beginning to arrive. Sam comes running, pulls  Stoltzfus toward the door of the milkhouse as the other A look at the shot-shattered bellrope. Rachel and Eli come  rapidly up the path toward the group.
Schaeffer finds another spent shotgun shell, crosses to t ladder, looks down. He sets his shotgun down, takes out h service revolver, starts down.

Book has reaches the third kickboard, about thirty feet f the ground. He checks it, turns the thumb-screws that hol it in place, places his hand on the handle, moves to one  side as best he can... hangs there, listening.
Rattling up the other ladder, approaching the third kickb
Listening tensely, hearing McElroy arrive on the other si of the kickboard. Then, deliberately, Book makes a fist,  raps on the board smartly once.
Startled, REACTING. He sets his feet, leans back against back wall of the ladder well, brings the shotgun up, puts the muzzle against the kickboard, clicks off the safety.

We HEAR with him the thump of the muzzle, the CLICK... an with marvelous speed, Book pulls the kickboard and drops to the floor. McELROY  FLASH CUT Staring in, stun-eyed, already falling forward (having leaned his weight on the shotgun) as Book seizes the shotgun by the barrel, pulls inward.

As McElroy pitches forward through the opening, SCREAMS a GRABS as he plunges past Book. The shotgun FIRES as McElr manages to hold onto Book, and both men plunge thirty fee to the bottom of the silo.
He falls almost straight down, lands on his back, lies  stunned.
His forward motion has carried him across the silo. His h bounds off the white brick wall about five feet up... and falls in a heap, blood gushing from his head, as...
Blinking, groaning, just beginning to stir... and, sudden into the frame comes a hand with a pistol in it. The muzz is placed firmly against Book's temple.
Schaeffer holding the pistol. He cocks the pistol, tenses if to FIRE (and he is actually about to)... when there is SOUND behind him. He snaps around.
Old Stoltzfus and Samuel standing in the kickboard openin (Schaeffer having kicked the kickboard in when he heard t shot from within the silo). They stand solemnly, looking as:
He eases the hammer down on this pistol, speaks softly:
Okay, Johnny. On your feet.

As Book struggles to his feet  Schaeffer holding the pist tight to Book's head. Book turns, sees Samuel and Stoltzf blinks. Schaeffer shoves Book toward the opening. As Book moves t Samuel, he speaks quietly:
It's okay, Sam.
As Book and McElroy move out of the silo, down the passag toward the milkhouse, Stoltzfus and Sam (after a glance i at the inert McElroy) follow and...

As first Stoltzfus and Samuel, then Book and Schaeffer em into the barnyard. Schaeffer has the muzzle of his pistol pressed firmly against Book's throat, just below his jaw. Schaeffer pulls up, frowning:
Hold it.
The Amishmen gathered  the Stoltzfus family, the Hochstet brothers, et al. All staring hard at Schaeffer and Book.
From a high wide angle the final scene is played out.  Schaeffer and Book, now moving again slowly up the drive, the Amish following along closely on both sides.
As Schaeffer prods Book forward, warily eyeing the Amish.
Get back, you people! (prodding) Keep moving, Johnny...
Book takes a couple of steps further, then abruptly stops The Amish stand about close, staring, no one moving. Book now slowly turns his head, looks at Schaeffer.
You're going to have to do it right  here, Schaeffer.
Don't try me, Johnny!
Eli steps forward, bloody cloth held to his head.
So... will you kill us all, then?
As Schaeffer's eyes waver between Book and Eli, Book slow turns until he is facing Schaeffer... the gun now leveled and almost pressing against  Book's chest. Book locks eye with Schaeffer. Quietly:
It's all over, Paul.
Move! Or you die right here!
Book's right hand snakes out, grabs Schaeffer by the gunh wrist, twists viciously, Schaeffer SCREAMS in pain, the g falls out of his hand, he starts to his knees under the f of Book's grip.

As Book bends, picks up the pistol, releases Schaeffer, p him away. Schaeffer staggers against Hochstetler, who  pa to keep him from falling, and partly (it appears) to  congratulate him on his surrender  wraps one brawny arm  around Schaeffer's shoulders, gives him a short approving nod... holds Schaeffer as:

Turning, looking into the crowd, finding Rachel. Their ga meet, hold for a long MOMENT. In the eyes of both we read resignation... whatever there was between them has been  terribly damaged. It is almost certainly over for them, t
HIGH SHOT holding the moment.
The door opens and Book steps out, looking somehow strang in his working suit. He looks about him, sees Samuel down the pond.
He eases down beside Samuel. They both stare into the pon
Are you really ever coming back?
Got to, Sam. You and I are going to  a courthouse together, put some people  behind bars.
Have you got your gun on now?
Sure have, Sam.
Sam grins. Book takes him in his arms, holds him.
Book opens the door of the car, turns to find Rachel stan there with his Amish hat in hand.
I want you to take this... to remember  by.
Where's my baggy pants?
Here. Whenever you want them.
He wants to kiss her, but does not. Their eyes say it all Eli has a final word, SHOUTING from the porch.
You be careful, John Book! Out among  them English!
Book gets quickly into the car.

As Book drives, he sees an open buggy coming down the hil toward the farm, He slows as he passes, It's Daniel  Hochstetler. A long beat, and as they pass, Hochstetler g Book an expansive tip of his hat.
Book turns to look back at his rival, a doubt in his eyes FREEZE FRAME.
